book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Praise be to Allah, who taught by the pen, taught man that which he knew not. And peace and blessings be upon the most noble Prophet, his family, his companions, and those who followed their most upright path. To proceed: These are brief lines and concise words that I place in the hands of the student of knowledge who desires to learn the rulings of Sharia and seeks to study its sciences. These are necessary introductions for the student of knowledge so that he may be insightful and aware of what is required of him before embarking on the quest for knowledge, to facilitate for him the attainment of his goal, and for Allah to bless his knowledge and guide his steps on the path of knowledge. These lines are divided into two parts: Part One: The etiquette of the seeker of truth and the qualities and beautiful traits he should possess during his quest, and what he must avoid that contradicts and opposes knowledge. Part Two: A brief overview of the sciences of Sharia, their most prominent divisions, the fruit of studying them, along with a number of the most important terms in each science. I do not forget to thank everyone who contributed to the production of this treatise. I ask Allah to make this work purely for His sake and to benefit His servants with it. And may Allah send peace and blessings upon our Prophet Muhammad. Written by Dr. Abdul Rahman bin Abdul Aziz Al-Aql, Faculty Member at the College of Sharia, Qassim University.

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Etiquette before Seeking Knowledge: Indeed, etiquette and adhering to the traits of people of good character is the beauty of knowledge. A little etiquette with some knowledge is better than much knowledge with poor etiquette. The predecessors (Imams) used to learn etiquette and strive for it just as they strove for knowledge itself or even more. They used to learn etiquette from their sheikhs just as they learned knowledge. Al-Hasan bin Ismail said: I heard my father say: "About five thousand or more would gather in Ahmad's assembly; less than five hundred would write, and the rest would learn from him good etiquette and good conduct" (1). Abu Bakr bin Al-Mutawwi'i said: "I frequented Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin Hanbal for twelve years while he was reading (Al-Musnad) to his children. I did not write a single hadith from him; I only used to observe his guidance, his character, and his etiquette" (2). The Imams believed that etiquette is the key to knowledge, and that a little of it is better than much knowledge devoid of etiquette. Sharik, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "A little etiquette is better than much knowledge" (3). And Makhlad bin Al-Hussein, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "We are more in need of a little etiquette than we are of much Hadith" (4).

Al-Hasan, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "A man would seek knowledge, and soon that would be seen in his humility, his guidance, his tongue, his sight, and his hand" (3). Regarding this, the poet says: Knowledge is light, and a person's ignorance is his darkness ... Would that we race towards the light of knowledge. The stars of knowledge are morals that adorn it ... A moral soul beautifies, and trusts not in whims. There are types of etiquette and forms of good morals that a student of knowledge should possess: etiquette with himself, etiquette with his teacher, etiquette with his colleagues, and etiquette with the general public. book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Type One: The student of knowledge's etiquette with himself: There are numerous etiquettes that a student of knowledge should adopt with his own self that lies between his sides. Many of them relate to his religious duties, which are rights of Allah the Almighty. They are attributed to him because he is required to establish them within himself and adorn himself with them in his words, deeds, conduct, and guidance. Among the most important of them are: (First: Sincerity of intention to Allah Almighty: Know, O student of knowledge, that sincerity is a secret between the servant and his Lord; no angel knows it to write it down, no human knows it to corrupt it, and no desire knows it to sway it. If you intend by seeking knowledge the Face of Allah, reward and recompense from Him, and the removal of ignorance from yourself and your Muslim brothers, know that this is divine success and a Lordly gift, so praise Allah for that. Continually examine your heart and strive against yourself in monitoring sincerity. Al-Hasan Al-Basri, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "A servant remains in goodness as long as when he speaks, he speaks for Allah, and when he acts, he acts for Allah Almighty" (1). Therefore, the intentions of seeking knowledge should be as follows: 1 - Reforming the heart and acting upon knowledge: One of the most beautiful fruits of knowledge is that it reforms the heart and the inner self. Here is Imam Ibn Jama'ah, may Allah have mercy on him, guiding you and whispering in your ears, saying: "Good intention in seeking knowledge is that he intends by it the Face of Allah Almighty, acting upon it, illuminating his heart, adorning his inner self,

text: drawing close to Allah Almighty on the Day of Resurrection, and exposing himself to what Allah has prepared for His people of His pleasure and great bounty" (1). These are among the greatest intentions of seeking knowledge. The aim is that drawing close to Allah through knowledge is one of the purest and most beloved acts of worship to Allah. 2 - Removing ignorance from oneself. 3 - Spreading knowledge, benefiting others, and doing good to Allah's servants: by guiding them and teaching them the religion. This is one of the greatest types of benevolence. Allah says: {And do good; indeed, Allah loves the doers of good} [Al-Baqarah: 195]. 4 - Defending the Sharia by disseminating knowledge and refuting the specious arguments of falsifiers. These four intentions are the fruit of knowledge. Whoever takes it rightfully, Allah loves him and grants him acceptance and awe among people. Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, said: "If the bearers of knowledge took it rightfully as it should be taken, Allah, His angels, and the righteous would love them, and people would hold them in awe. But they sought the world with it, so Allah hated them, and they became despicable to people" (2). He means by that: those who stripped their intention for other than Allah and wanted the world by seeking knowledge. As for the one who intended by knowledge one of the four previous intentions, or wanted thereby to obtain a position through which he serves Muslims, or wanted by knowledge a job to enrich himself from begging people and to fulfill the obligatory spending on his family, he does not fall under the station of blame, even if he misses the greatest purpose of knowledge.

text: And on the authority of Abu Yusuf, may Allah have mercy on him, he said: "O people, intend Allah by your knowledge; for I never sat in a gathering intending to humble myself except that I did not stand up until I surpassed them, and I never sat in a gathering intending to surpass them except that I did not stand up until I was exposed" (1). Treating the Intention: Sincere people agree that intention does not become upright for a servant except through long maintenance and much struggle. Sufyan Al-Thawri, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "I have not treated anything harder on me than my intention; indeed, it turns over on me" (2). This does not mean that a student of knowledge should turn away from seeking knowledge and cut himself off from it on the pretext that his intention is not pure. This is an entrance of Satan to turn the servant away from Sharia knowledge. Rather, the student of knowledge must proceed on the path of seeking knowledge, ascend the ladder of knowledge, and strive against himself to correct the intention at the beginning of the quest and during the quest, indeed in all stages of the quest. This striving helps the student to be sincere and seek the Face of Allah Almighty. With continuous striving and diligence in seeking sincerity, the servant is granted success for a righteous intention and good work; because knowledge by its nature nurtures sincerity. Ishaq bin Rahwayh, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "I asked Waki' about a man who seeks knowledge, and his intention is to discuss it and narrate it or something similar; do you think he sins in that? He said: No,

text: O son of my brother. Sufyan told us, from Habib bin Abi Thabit, who said: We sought this knowledge, and we had no intention in it, then the intention and action came afterwards" (1). Punishment of One Who Seeks Knowledge for Other Than Allah: Whoever seeks knowledge for showing off, reputation, and fame, or to attain a worldly objective, is threatened with punishment. Indeed, it is reported that he is among the first with whom the Fire will be kindled on the Day of Resurrection. On the authority of Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "Indeed, the first of people to be judged on the Day of Resurrection will be a man who was martyred. He will be brought and Allah will make him recognize His blessings and he will recognize them. He (Allah) will say: 'What did you do with them?' He will say: 'I fought for You until I was martyred.' He (Allah) will say: 'You have lied. You fought so that it might be said [that you were] brave, and it was said.' Then he will be ordered to be dragged on his face until he is cast into the Fire. And [then] a man who learned knowledge and taught it and read the Quran. He will be brought and Allah will make him recognize His blessings and he will recognize them. He (Allah) will say: 'What did you do with them?' He will say: 'I learned knowledge and taught it and read the Quran for You.' He (Allah) will say: 'You have lied. You learned knowledge so that it might be said [that you were] a scholar, and you read the Quran so that it might be said [that you were] a reciter, and it was said.' Then he will be ordered to be dragged on his face until he is cast into the Fire. And [then] a man to whom Allah had expanded [wealth] and given from all types of wealth. He will be brought and Allah will make him recognize His blessings and he will recognize them. He (Allah) will say: 'What did you do with them?' He will say: 'I did not leave any path in which You like money to be spent without spending in it for You.' He (Allah) will say: 'You have lied. You did it so that it might be said [that you were] generous, and it was said.' Then he will be ordered to be dragged on his face until he is cast into the Fire" (2).

text: And in a narration: "O Abu Hurairah, those three are the first of Allah's creation with whom the Fire will be kindled on the Day of Resurrection" (1). (Second: Acting upon Knowledge: The goal and fruit of knowledge is that a person acts upon it hoping for Allah's reward, to win His Paradise, and to be saved from His punishment. Imam Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi, may Allah have mercy on him, authored a book titled "Iqtida' Al-Ilm Al-Amal" (The Demand of Knowledge for Action), in which he spoke about the necessity of acting upon knowledge as is clear from its title, and it is worthy of study, review, and reading. A person will be asked on the Day of Resurrection about his knowledge: what did he do with it, and did he act upon it or not? On the authority of Abu Barzah Al-Aslami, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The feet of a servant will not move on the Day of Resurrection until he is asked about his life and how he spent it, about his knowledge and what he did with it, about his wealth, from where he acquired it and in what he spent it, and about his body and how he wore it out" (2). Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Knowledge calls out to action; if it answers, [it stays], otherwise it departs" (3). The meaning of (hatafa) is called out and shouted (4). Abu Qilabah, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "If Allah grants you new knowledge, then grant Allah new worship, and let not your concern be to narrate it to people" (5).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: If a Muslim acts upon his knowledge, he wins the pleasure of Allah Almighty and attains His Paradise: Act upon your knowledge, you will profit, O man ... Knowledge is of no avail if actions are not good. Knowledge is an adornment, and the fear of Allah is its decoration ... And the pious are occupied with their knowledge. Learn knowledge and act upon it as much as you can ... Let not amusement and argumentation distract you from it (1). The predecessors (Salaf), may Allah have mercy on them, were among the most keen people to act upon knowledge and the quickest to apply it in their daily lives. On the authority of Abu Abd Al-Rahman Al-Sulami, he said: "Those who used to teach us the Quran from the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, told us: That they used to learn ten verses from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and they would not take the next ten until they knew what was in these [first ten] of knowledge and action. For we were taught knowledge and action. He said: So we learned knowledge and action together. And the Quran will be inherited after us by a people who will drink it like water, it will not go beyond this - and he pointed with his hand to his jaw" (2). The Salaf represented wonderful examples in initiating compliance and quickly applying knowledge: Imam Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, did not hold the permissibility of wiping over socks (Jawrabayn), then he returned to the view of permissibility three or seven days before his death, and he wiped over his socks during his illness, and said to his visitors: I did what I used to forbid (3).

text: And here is Imam Malik, may Allah have mercy on him: Ibn Wahb narrated from him saying: "I heard Malik being asked about running fingers between the toes in Wudu', and he said: That is not [incumbent] upon people. He said: So I left him until the people decreased, then I said to him: We have a Sunnah regarding that. He said: And what is it? I said: Al-Layth ibn Sa'd, Ibn Lahi'ah, and Amr bin Al-Harith told us, from Yazid bin Amr Al-Ma'afiri, from Abu Abd Al-Rahman Al-Hubuli, from Al-Mustawrid bin Shaddad Al-Qurashi who said: I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, rubbing between his toes with his little finger. He said: This hadith is good (Hasan), and I have never heard it except this hour. Then I heard him after that being asked, and he commanded the running of fingers [between toes]" (1). As for Imam Al-Shafi'i, the example in him is clearer and greater; his Old School in Iraq and New School in Egypt are famous. He retracted his Old School in his New School except for a few issues which some counted as seventeen issues, and others counted as thirty-odd issues, and that was due to his discovering the correct evidence. And here is Imam Ahmad bin Hanbal, may Allah have mercy on him, who did not write a hadith from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, except after he acted upon it. Al-Marwadhi said: Ahmad said to me: "I did not write a hadith from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, except that I acted upon it, until the hadith passed by me: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was cupped and gave Abu Taybah a dinar, so I gave the cupper a dinar when I was cupped" (2). A severe threat has come against the one who does not act upon his knowledge. On the authority of Usama bin Zaid, may Allah be pleased with them,

The people of the Fire will gather around him and say: 'O so-and-so, what is the matter with you? Did you not used to enjoin good and forbid evil?' He will say: 'Yes, I used to enjoin good but not do it, and forbid evil and do it'" (3). Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "You will not be a scholar until you are a learner, and you will not be a learner until you are an actor upon what you know" (4). Ibn Ruslan, may Allah have mercy on him, said: And a scholar who does not act upon his knowledge ... Is punished before the worshippers of idols. (Third: Fear of Allah and awe of Him: Beneficial knowledge is that which cultivates the soul, purifies it from bad qualities, and bequeaths fear of Allah and humility towards His creation. Thus, its possessor becomes a good example among people, and a righteous role model in words and deeds (5). Allah Almighty says: {It is only those who have knowledge among His slaves that fear Allah} [Fatir: 28].

text: "Meaning: Only the scholars who know Him truly fear Him as He should be feared; because the more complete the knowledge of the Great, Powerful, All-Knowing, described with attributes of perfection and named with the Beautiful Names, the greater and more abundant the fear of Him becomes" (1). Abdullah bin Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Knowledge is not the narration of Hadith, but knowledge is fear [of Allah]" (2). Yahya bin Abi Kathir, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "The scholar is the one who fears Allah, and fear of Allah is piety" (3). Malik, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Knowledge is not by abundance of narration; rather, knowledge is a light that Allah places in the heart" (4). (Fourth: Avoiding Sins: The student of knowledge must stay away from disobeying Allah Almighty, avoid paths of destruction, and beware of tracks of deadly sins, for sins destroy their perpetrator and throw him into a deep ravine. No calamity befalls a servant except due to a sin he committed. Allah Almighty says: {And whatever strikes you of disaster - it is for what your hands have earned; but He pardons much} [Ash-Shura: 30].

text: Ibn Al-Jawzi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "And know that sins block the doors of provision, and that whoever neglects the command of Allah, Allah will neglect him" (1). There is nothing more beneficial for a student of knowledge in preserving his knowledge, strengthening his understanding, recall, and perception than fearing Allah and staying away from sins. Waki', may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Seek help in memorization by abandoning sin" (2). Ibn Hibban, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "And among the best things a person uses to aid memorization is good nature along with high ambition, and avoiding sins" (3). Al-Nawawi said - speaking about the etiquette of the student of knowledge -: "He should purify his heart from impurities so that it becomes fit to receive knowledge, preserve it, and invest it" (4). Whoever leans towards sin and finds sins agreeable forgets his knowledge, his mind becomes confused, and he is punished with much forgetfulness. Ibn Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "I truly think a servant forgets knowledge he used to know because of a sin he commits" (5). May Allah have mercy on Imam Al-Shafi'i when he said:

text: I complained to Waki' about my poor memory ... So he guided me to abandon sins. And he informed me that knowledge is light ... And the light of Allah is not guided to a sinner. (Fifth: Worship and Remembrance (Dhikr): Perpetuating the remembrance of Allah, seeking His forgiveness, and praising Him are among the most beautiful forms of servitude, and causes for the heart's purity, health, clarity, and tranquility. {Those who have believed and whose hearts are assured by the remembrance of Allah. Unquestionably, by the remembrance of Allah hearts are assured} [Ar-Ra'd: 28]. Indeed, the remembrance of Allah fills the heart with light and joy; rather, without it, the heart is in darkness and gloom; because "In the heart there is a void and poverty that nothing can fill at all except the remembrance of Allah Almighty. If remembrance becomes the slogan of the heart such that it is the rememberer fundamentally and the tongue follows it, this is the remembrance that fills the void and ends the poverty. Its possessor becomes rich without wealth, powerful without clan, awe-inspiring without authority. If he is heedless of the remembrance of Allah Almighty, he is the opposite of that: poor despite great wealth, humiliated despite authority, contemptible despite a large clan" (1). The student of knowledge is the most deserving of people to maintain the remembrance of Allah Almighty, and to have a share of Sunan, voluntary prayers, fasting, night prayer (Qiyam al-Layl), and reading the Holy Quran. It is ugly for a student of knowledge to be negligent in his worship. On the authority of Abu Ismah Asim bin Isam Al-Bayhaqi, he said: "I spent a night with Ahmad bin Hanbal, so he brought water

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: and placed it. When morning came, he looked at the water and found it as it was. He said: Glory be to Allah! A man seeks knowledge and has no litany (Wird) at night?!" (1). Indeed, the predecessors (Salaf), may Allah have mercy on them, used to seek help in memorizing knowledge through worship and draw closer to Allah through it so He would open for them the locks of knowledge. Ibrahim bin Ismail said: "Our companions used to seek help in seeking Hadith through fasting" (2). (Sixth: Turning to Allah with abundant Supplication (Dua): Supplication is the essence of worship and pure devotion; because it involves complete neediness of Allah and humility before Him. It is the most beneficial worship of the heart and has the most effect on it, especially if the heart of the supplicant is present and he evokes the meanings of what he prays for. If those supplications and invocations are from what Allah Almighty reported of the supplications of His chosen creation, they are most effective for the heart; because they contain the comprehensive words of supplication, true humility, and evocation of the meanings of Lordship (Rububiyyah); that is why they used to start their supplications by saying: "Our Lord" (Rabbana). Most supplications in the Quran also come started with seeking means to Allah through His Lordship. It is good for the supplicant, when calling upon Allah using His Lordship as a means, to evoke the meaning of Allah's general nurturing, which is: Creation and Management, and the meaning of special nurturing, which is: His guardianship of the best of His creation, His kindness to them, and His reforming of their religion and worldly life, due to their turning to their Lord and their humility before Him.

2. Narrated by Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi in Al-Jami' li Akhlaq Al-Rawi wa Adab Al-Sami' (1/143) number (177).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: It is good for the supplicant to pray with the supplication of those firmly grounded in knowledge; because when He, Glory be to Him, praised them, He mentioned their call: {Our Lord, let not our hearts deviate after You have guided us and grant us from Yourself mercy. Indeed, You are the Bestower} [Ali 'Imran: 8]. So they sought means to Allah through His Lordship to grant them steadfastness of hearts and their firmness upon what pleases Allah, and their preservation from deviation and turning back from guidance (1). (Seventh: Evoking Allah's Bounty and Favor: The successful student of knowledge is the one who constantly evokes the scenes of his Lord's favors upon him, which no book can enumerate and no counter can count; because they have surrounded the believer with a collar filling the earth and the sky. He is the One who poured upon him blessings, the highest of which is the blessing of guidance, which the tongue fails to fulfill its worth, as his Lord brought him out by it from the darkness of misguidance to the light of guidance and the vastness of faith, "O My servants, all of you are astray except those whom I have guided, so seek guidance of Me and I shall guide you" (2). Therefore, Allah admonished those who neglected witnessing His favors, saying: {They consider it a favor to you that they have accepted Islam. Say, "Do not consider your Islam a favor to me. Rather, Allah has conferred favor upon you that He has guided you to the faith} [Al-Hujurat: 17]. It is the Quranic upbringing that strips the heart of arrogance, erases from it the paths of self-admiration, and fills it with reverence for Allah and acknowledgment of His bounty and favor. This was understood by those of determination and virtue like Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, when he was stabbed and Abdullah bin Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, said to him consoling: "O Commander of the Faithful, even if that [death] happens, you accompanied the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and you were good in his companionship, then you parted from him while he was pleased with you. Then you accompanied Abu Bakr and were good in his companionship,
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Mawahib Al-Rabbaniyyah min Al-Ayat Al-Quraniyyah by Al-Sa'di p. (56 - 58).
2. Narrated by Muslim (4/1994) number (2577) from the hadith of Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him.

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: then you parted from him while he was pleased with you. Then you accompanied them [the companions] and were good in their companionship, and if you part from them, you will part from them while they are pleased with you." He said: "As for what you mentioned of the companionship of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his pleasure, that is but a favor from Allah Almighty which He bestowed upon me. And as for what you mentioned of the companionship of Abu Bakr and his pleasure, that is but a favor from Allah, Exalted is His mention, which He bestowed upon me. And as for what you see of my anxiety, it is for your sake and the sake of your companions. By Allah, if I had the earth full (1) of gold, I would have ransomed myself with it from the punishment of Allah Almighty before I see Him" (2). The servant's evocation of Allah's favor upon him removes the haze of vanity from the heart, washes it from the filth of self-admiration, and purifies it from impurity so that it becomes a clean vessel that is purified by faith, rises with the actions of the heart, and benefits from the actions of the limbs. However, if these actions exist with the impurities of vanity and self-admiration for the deed, they crush the heart of their owner completely, leaving no good in it. Allah Almighty says in the Qudsi Hadith about the one who boasted of his deed: "I have forgiven so-and-so, and thwarted your deed" (3). So kindle, O student of knowledge, in your mind the spark of feeling Allah's favor and His purification of you, {And if not for the favor of Allah upon you and His mercy, not one of you would have been pure, ever, but Allah purifies whom He wills, and Allah is Hearing and Knowing} [An-Nur: 21].
foot_note:
1. Meaning: What fills it until it overflows and runs over. See: Al-Nihaya fi Gharib Al-Hadith (3/133).
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (5/12) number (3692) from the hadith of Al-Miswar bin Makhramah, may Allah be pleased with him.
3. Narrated by Muslim (4/2023) number (2621) from the hadith of Jundub, may Allah be pleased with him.

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: (Eighth: Adorning oneself with the qualities of Muru'ah (Chivalry/Manliness): Indeed, what adorns the student of knowledge and beautifies him is adorning himself with (Muru'ah): such as noble manners, a cheerful face, spreading peace (Salam), bearing with people, dignity without pride, might without tyranny, and magnanimity without tribalism or ignorance. Therefore, he must avoid things that violate Muru'ah, whether in nature, speech, or action, such as a degrading profession, or a bad trait like vanity, showing off, arrogance, haughtiness, looking down on others, and frequenting places of suspicion; all of that corrupts knowledge for its seeker (1). (Ninth: Moderation and Avoiding Extremism: Islamic Sharia came with moderation, between extremism and negligence, and between excess and deficiency. Allah Almighty said: {And thus we have made you a just community that you will be witnesses over the people and the Messenger will be a witness over you} [Al-Baqarah: 143]. Warning the People of the Book against extremism in religion has come as in the saying of Allah Glory be to Him: {O People of the Scripture, do not commit excess in your religion or say about Allah except the truth} [An-Nisa: 171]. Then came the warning to us about this chronic disease into which the Jews and Christians fell. On the authority of Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Beware of extremism in religion, for indeed those before you were destroyed by extremism in religion" (2).
foot_note:
1. Hilyat Talib Al-Ilm p. (149) with modification.
2. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i (5/268) number (3057), Ibn Majah (2/1008) number (3029), Ahmad (3/351) number (1851), Ibn Khuzaimah (4/274) number (2867), and Al-Hakim in Al-Mustadrak (1/637) number (1711), and he said: "Authentic according to the conditions of the two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim)."

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: That is because extremism is destructive and leads a person to error and deviation from the path of truth. On the authority of Abdullah bin Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Perished are the extremists (Mutanatti'un), he said it three times" (1). So the consequence of extremism is dire, and its outcome is ugly. Look at the Christians, how extremism regarding the Prophet of Allah Jesus, peace be upon him, led them to make him a god and a lord! And how extremism led the Khawarij until it caused them to fall into declaring Muslims disbelievers and making their blood lawful, to the point that they declared major Companions disbelievers, including Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him. The methodology of the Khawarij remains in the Ummah, weakening in one era and strengthening in another. In this era, it has reached its peak in declaring Muslims disbelievers, disregarding bloodshed, and distorting the image of Islam in the corners of the world. So we ask Allah to protect Muslims from their evils and guide them to His straight path. The Muslim must take matters with moderation and deliberation, beware of anomaly and extremism, be gentle with himself and his brothers, and endear himself to Allah's creation and endear Allah's religion to them. On the authority of Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, this religion is firm, so penetrate into it with gentleness" (2). And on the authority of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Indeed, gentleness is not found in anything except that it adorns it, and it is not removed from anything except that it defects it" (3).
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Muslim (4/2055) number (2670).
2. Narrated by Ahmad in Al-Musnad (20/346) number (13052). This Hadith, although there is some discussion about it, is Hasan (good) due to its supporting evidences.
3. Narrated by Muslim (4/2004) number (2594).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: (Tenth: Open-mindedness in matters of disagreement: One of the most wonderful qualities that adorns knowledge and beautifies its possessor is to be broad-chested and open-minded in dialogue, calm in spirit during disagreement without anger, tension, or nervousness. Here are important matters that a student of knowledge must understand well and observe: 1 - Disagreement is an existing universal norm: Disagreement is an existing universal norm, and its cause is the difference in perceptions, intellects, and understandings. The Salaf among the Companions and those after them differed in the past, and the later generations after them also. Scholars may differ regarding the authenticity of a text or its understanding, and its indication of the intended meaning, as well as their difference in Qiyas (analogy), the saying of a Companion, blocking the means (Sadd al-Dhara'i), and other evidences that are a cause for the emergence of disagreement. 2 - No denial in matters of Ijtihad: A student of knowledge should know that one of the rules established by scholars is that "there is no denial in matters of Ijtihad". So it is not permissible for a student of knowledge to denounce anyone in a matter based on Ijtihad, and most issues of religious rulings are of this type. That is why you find the knowledgeable scholar the most open-minded person regarding matters of disagreement because he knows they are based on Ijtihad. 3 - Not to put oneself forward for Fatwa nor be bold in it: The Salaf were the most pious people regarding Fatwa, and they set the most beautiful examples for that, to the point that Ibn Al-Jawzi wrote a book he named (Ta'zim Al-Futya - Magnifying Fatwa) in which he mentioned wonderful images of the Salaf in their caution against putting themselves forward for Fatwa.
foot_note: None

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: In our time, a young person might take upon himself to issue a fatwa on a complex issue which, if presented to the great scholars of the Salaf, they would have refrained from answering. Abu Al-Husayn said: "One of them gives a fatwa on an issue that if it were presented to (Umar), he would have gathered the people of Badr for it" (1). 4 - A student of knowledge should not force people to his opinion: Ahmad said in the narration of Al-Marwadhi: "It is not befitting for a jurist to force people to his Madhhab (school of thought), nor be harsh on them" (2). Therefore, the methodology of the Salaf was: "My opinion is correct but accepts the possibility of error, and the opinion of others is wrong but accepts the possibility of correctness" (3). This is a beautiful rule that outlines the correct methodology in dealing with the opinions and Ijtihads of others. It is a rule that whoever follows it, his mind expands in dealing with situations and opinions. Ibn Uthaymeen said - while listing the etiquettes of a student of knowledge -: "That his chest be broad in areas of disagreement that stem from Ijtihad; because issues of disagreement among scholars are either those where there is no room for Ijtihad and the matter is clear, so no one is excused for opposing them, or they are those where there is room for Ijtihad, so the one who opposes in them is excused. Your opinion is not a proof against the one who opposes you in it; because if we accepted that, we would say conversely that his opinion is a proof against you" (4).
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Ibn Batta in Ibtal Al-Hiyal p. (62), Al-Bayhaqi in Al-Madkhal ila Al-Sunan Al-Kubra p. (434) number (803), and Ibn Asakir in Tarikh Dimashq (38/410, 411).
2. Al-Adab Al-Shar'iyyah by Ibn Muflih (1/166).
3. See: Al-Ashbah wa Al-Naza'ir by Ibn Nujaim p. (330).
4. Kitab Al-Ilm p. (23, 24).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: 5 - Not to base Takfir (declaring someone a disbeliever), Tabdi' (declaring someone an innovator), or Tadlil (declaring someone misguided) on disagreement: The Mujtahid in knowledge is not declared a disbeliever, nor misguided, nor a sinner, because he revolves between one reward and two rewards; if he is correct he gets two rewards, and if he errs he gets one reward. This confirms the Hadith of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "If a judge judges and strives (exercises Ijtihad) and is correct, he has two rewards. And if he judges and strives and errs, he has one reward" (1). 6 - Excusing the Imams and Mujtahid scholars: This is a duty of the Ummah towards its scholars who are the heirs of the prophets. For this reason, Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah wrote an enjoyable book titled (Raf' Al-Malam 'an Al-A'immah Al-A'lam - Lifting the Blame from the Eminent Imams) in which he explained the excuse of the Imams in their contradiction of some texts, and their error in Ijtihad. Among these excuses: that the Hadith did not reach him, or that the Hadith was not proven authentic to him, or that he forgot the Hadith, or his lack of knowledge of the indication of the Hadith, and other excuses. 7 - Adhering to etiquette in disagreement with scholars and those having precedence in Islam: This is done by not disparaging them or attacking them, and mentioning them with goodness and beauty even if they opposed the correct view, and he chose other than their saying (2). And "The flesh of scholars is poisonous, and Allah's custom in exposing those who belittle them is well known" (3).
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (9/108) number (7352), and Muslim (3/1342) number (1716) from the hadith of Amr bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with him.
2. This etiquette is discussed extensively in the book Fiqh Al-I'tilaf by Mahmoud Muhammad Al-Khanzadar.
3. Tabyin Kadhib Al-Muftari by Ibn Asakir p. (29).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Type Two: The Student's Etiquette with His Sheikh: The Sheikh or teacher has a great right over his students. He has great merit - after Allah Almighty - in teaching them knowledge and taking their hands towards the path of knowledge and traversing the way of salvation. Hence, it is a duty to observe the right of the teacher; by appreciating and revering him, and observing his rights. This is from the core of knowledge, good manners, and nobility of soul. Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "I am the slave of him who taught me a single letter; if he wishes he may sell, and if he wishes he may enslave" (1). Al-Zurnuji, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Know that the student of knowledge does not attain knowledge nor benefit from it except by venerating knowledge and its people, and venerating the professor and revering him. It was said: No one arrived (at success) except through reverence (2), and no one fell except by abandoning reverence" (3). "And from the reverence of the teacher: that he does not walk in front of him, nor sit in his place, nor initiate speech in his presence except with his permission, nor speak much in his presence, nor ask anything when he is weary, and he should observe the time, and not knock on the door, but wait until the professor comes out" (4).
foot_note:
1. Ta'lim Al-Muta'allim Tariq Al-Ta'allum p. (25).
2. The meaning of reverence (Hurma): respecting the Sheikh and being polite with him.
3. Ta'lim Al-Muta'allim Tariq Al-Ta'allum p. (25).
4. Ta'lim Al-Muta'allim Tariq Al-Ta'allum p. (26).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Among the masterpieces of etiquette with the teacher are the following: First: Etiquette in addressing him: Indeed, it is from beautiful reverence and high etiquette that the student observes manners in addressing his sheikh and teacher; so he does not call him by his bare name, but rather he must address him with speech of reverence, appreciation, and respect, saying to him: O our Sheikh, or O my Sheikh. If it is not fitting for a child to say to his biological father: (O So-and-so) or: (O my father So-and-so), then likewise it is not fitting for him to address with such speech his sheikh who taught him, raised him, and disciplined him (1). The basis for that is the saying of Allah Almighty: {Do not make [your] calling of the Messenger among yourselves as the call of one of you to another} [An-Nur: 63]. The meaning of the noble verse: "Do not call Muhammad by his name, peace and blessings be upon him, like the calling of one of you to another, but revere him and honor him, and say: O Messenger of Allah, O Prophet of Allah, O Abu Al-Qasim. In the verse is a clarification of revering the teacher of good; because the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was the teacher of good, so Allah Almighty commanded his reverence and honoring. In it is the recognition of the right of the professor, and in it is the recognition of people of virtue" (2). The prohibition in His saying: {Do not make [your] calling of the Messenger among yourselves as the call of one of you to another} [An-Nur: 63], is by way of prohibition (Tahrim) regarding the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and by way of contrary to what is best (Khilaf Al-Awla) regarding other than the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, among the people of knowledge and all teachers.
foot_note:
1. See: Hilyat Talib Al-Ilm p. (162), and Mawsu'at Al-Akhlaq by Al-Kharraz p. (327).
2. Bahr Al-Ulum (2/527).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Second: Etiquette in asking questions: The student of knowledge's questioning of his sheikh should observe the following: 1 - Supplicating for the Sheikh in the question: Like saying: What do you say, may Allah pardon you, or may Allah have mercy on you, or may Allah grant you success, or may Allah be good to you? (1). 2 - Good questioning and gentleness in it: Indeed, among the wisdoms that have become famous among people: Good questioning is half of knowledge (2). They do not differ on this matter; for if the questioner asks his sheikh well, that calls for him to turn to him to clarify what was confusing to him; because of what he sees of his readiness and receptivity for that. And bad questioning calls for the sheikh to turn away from the student and answering him because of what he sees of his rudeness; so the student is deprived of much good thereby (3). This has been narrated from some of the Salaf: Muhammad bin Sirin said: "They used to consider good questioning to increase a man's intellect" (4). Al-Nawawi said - in his discussion of the student's etiquette with his sheikh -: "And he should be gentle in his questioning, and improve his address" (5).
foot_note:
1. Al-Faqih wa Al-Mutafaqqih by Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi (2/383).
2. Sulaiman bin Yasar said: (Good questioning is half of knowledge) narrated by Ibn Abi Khaythama in Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir (2/150) number (2152).
3. Al-Tayseer bi Sharh Al-Jami' Al-Saghir (1/424).
4. Narrated by Ibn Abi Al-Dunya in Kitab Al-Aql wa Fadlih p. (54) number (66).
5. Al-Majmu' Sharh Al-Muhadhdhab (1/37).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: 3 - Not insisting in questioning: That is by "not asking him about something out of its place unless he knows from his state that he does not dislike it, nor insisting in asking an annoying insistence, and seizing the opportunity to ask him when he is in good spirits and free, and being gentle in his questioning, and improving his address" (1). 4 - Seizing the appropriate time for questioning: That is by seeking the best times to ask his sheikh, so he does not ask him in a state of annoyance, boredom, or anger; lest the opposite of truth be conceived with the confusion of the mind, and the least of cases is that the answer falls short (2). "And if he sees him in a worry that has befallen him, or a matter that comes between him and his mind, and prevents him from fully utilizing his thought, he should refrain from him, until that obstacle is removed, and he returns to the usual state of calmness of heart and goodness of soul, then he asks him" (3). And Al-Nawawi said: "And he seizes the opportunity to ask him when he is in good spirits and free" (4). 6 - Do not be shy to ask about what confuses you: Mujahid, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "No shy person nor arrogant person learns knowledge" (5). The serious student "does not shy away from asking about what confuses him, rather he seeks clarification most completely. For whoever has a thin face (shy), his knowledge becomes thin, and whoever has a thin face when asking, his deficiency appears when meeting men" (6).

4. Al-Majmu' Sharh Al-Muhadhdhab (1/37).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Also, he should, if the Sheikh says to him: Did you understand? not say: Yes, until the intended meaning becomes clearly evident to him; lest he lies and misses understanding: He should not be shy of saying: I did not understand; because verifying gains him immediate and deferred benefits: Of the immediate is memorizing the issue, and his safety from lying by showing understanding of what he did not understand (1). Third: Respecting the Sheikh: This is from the etiquette that the student of knowledge must follow. He should not argue with his sheikh nor harm him, nor be obstinate with him in dialogue and questioning; for the student might be deprived of benefit due to the ominousness of his dealing with his sheikh. No one angered his teacher except that he was deprived of his knowledge. Ibn Hazm, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "If you attend a gathering of knowledge, let your presence be only the presence of one seeking increase in knowledge and reward, not the presence of one who thinks he can do without what you have; seeking a slip to spread, or a strange thing to defame. These are the actions of the vile, who never succeed in knowledge. If you attend with this intention, you have obtained good in any case. And if you do not attend with this intention, your sitting in your house is more restful for your body, more honorable for your character, and safer for your religion" (2). Indeed, the teacher and the doctor, both of them ... Do not advise if they are not honored. So be patient with your illness if you insulted its doctor ... And be patient with your ignorance if you were harsh to a teacher.
foot_note:
1. Al-Majmu' Sharh Al-Muhadhdhab (1/37) with slight modification.
2. Al-Akhlaq wa Al-Siyar fi Mudawat Al-Nufus p. (92).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Al-Sha'bi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Abu Salamah (1) used to argue with Ibn Abbas; so he was deprived of much knowledge thereby" (2), and was deprived of benefiting from him. Abu Salamah admitted that and regretted his behavior and was remorseful for what happened. He said at the end of his life: "If I had been gentle with Ibn Abbas; I would have obtained much knowledge from him" (3). "And among the etiquettes of the learner: That he seeks the pleasure of the teacher even if it contradicts his own opinion, does not backbite in his presence, does not reveal a secret to him, defends him against backbiting if he hears it, and if he is unable, he leaves that assembly; and he should not enter upon him without permission, and if a group enters, they should put forward the best and oldest of them" (4). The Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, used to teach their students and raise them to ask about what benefits and leave what does not benefit. Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said one day: "Ask me whatever you wish. Ibn Al-Kawwa' (5) said: What is the blackness in the moon? He said: That belongs to Allah. Did you not ask about what benefits you in your religion and your hereafter? That is the erasure of the night. He said: Tell us about His saying: {And those [clouds] carrying a load [of water]}

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: [Al-Dhariyat: 2]. He said: May your mother lose you, ask to understand, do not ask to be obstinate. Ask about what concerns you, and leave what does not concern you" (1). "Thus were the scholars and wise men when asked about what knowledge does not benefit the questioner, nor ignorance harm him. Or perhaps the answer was also something the questioner could not grasp, nor his understanding reach, they withheld the answer from him, and perhaps they rebuked and scolded him" (2). If a student of knowledge wants to benefit from his sheikh and obtain his knowledge, he must be patient with harshness coming from him, or bad temper. That should not deter him from sticking with him and benefiting from his knowledge. He should think well of his sheikh, interpret his actions and words that appear contrary to what is correct in the best possible interpretation as much as possible, construe them in the best ways, and strive to find excuses for him. Also, the student of knowledge must bear from his sheikh if he rebukes him or gets angry with him: "It was said to Sufyan bin Uyaynah: People come to you from the corners of the earth, you get angry with them, they are about to go and leave you? He said: They are fools then, like you, if they leave what benefits them because of my bad temper!" (3). Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi titled a chapter in his collection: Chapter "Gentleness with the Muhaddith, and bearing with him when angry" (4).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Be patient with the bitterness of harshness from a teacher ... For the establishment of knowledge is in his aversion. And whoever has not tasted the bitterness of learning for an hour ... Will swallow the humiliation of ignorance for the length of his life. So whoever does not endure the humiliation of learning remains throughout his life in the blindness of ignorance, and whoever endures it, his affair ends in the honor of this world and the Hereafter. From Ibn Abbas: I was humble as a seeker, so I became mighty as a sought-after one. Fourth: Thanking him for his kindness to him: Allah says: {And do not forget graciousness between you} [Al-Baqarah: 237]. And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever does not thank people does not thank Allah" (1). It is obligatory upon a Muslim to preserve the favor for the one who was kind to him, and not forget his merit whoever he may be, so how about the one who was kind to you with knowledge, which is the most majestic aspect of kindness. Sheikh al-Islam, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "And if a man has been taught by a professor, he recognizes the value of his kindness to him and thanks him" (2). He also said: "And upon the learner is to know the sanctity of his professor and thank his kindness to him; for whoever does not thank people does not thank Allah, and he should not deny his right nor reject his favor" (3).

3. Majmu' Al-Fatawa (28/13).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Also, the learner should praise Allah for facilitating for him someone to teach him from his ignorance, revive him from his death, and wake him from his slumber. He should seize the opportunity at all times to learn from him, and increase in supplication for him, present or absent, for the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever does you a favor, recompense him; but if you cannot find the means to do so, then pray for him until you feel that you have compensated him" (1). And what favor is greater than the favor of knowledge, and every favor is cut off except the favor of knowledge, advice, and upbringing. So every issue benefited from a person and above - by which benefit occurred to its learner and others - is a favor and good deeds flowing for its owner (2). Among the nice things reported from the Salaf in this regard is what Yahya bin Saeed Al-Qattan said: "I pray to Allah Almighty for Al-Shafi'i in every prayer, or every day", meaning: for what Allah Almighty opened for him of knowledge, and guided him to correctness in it (3). On the authority of Muhammad bin Ishaq bin Rahwayh, he said: "My father, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Few nights passed but I prayed for those who wrote from us and those we wrote from" (4). Fifth: To attribute the merit to him: This is an etiquette that a student of knowledge should possess, and to preserve the favor of his sheikh and his merit upon him. Shu'bah, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Everyone from whom I wrote a hadith, I am a slave to him" (5).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Scholars have stated this in their books that contained such etiquettes: Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Likewise, the learner must acknowledge the virtue of the jurist, and admit that he acquired knowledge from his direction, and took it from him" (1). Therefore, the guidance of scholars and Imams was that they attribute every good and virtue to their sheikhs and Imams: Ahmad bin Hanbal, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "This that you see, all or most of it, is from Al-Shafi'i, and I haven't spent a night for thirty years except that I pray for Al-Shafi'i" (2). Al-Sa'di, may Allah have mercy on him, said in the introduction to his poem on Fiqh maxims: So these are maxims I composed ... From the books of the people of knowledge I obtained them. May the Master reward them with great reward ... And pardon along with His forgiveness and piety. This Imam Al-Sa'di, may Allah have mercy on him, composes this poem on Fiqh maxims, then attributes the merit in it to the people of knowledge in recognition of their great favor and generous bounty upon him. How beautiful it is to acknowledge merit to the people of merit, and return the favor to the people of favor.

2. Narrated by Abu Nu'aym in Hilyat Al-Awliya (9/98).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Type Three: The Student's Etiquette with His Colleagues: There are some etiquettes that a student of knowledge should observe with his colleagues and brothers, including: First: Avoiding Envy: Allah says: {Or do they envy people for what Allah has given them of His bounty?} [An-Nisa: 54]. Allah Almighty condemns in this noble verse the envious people who object to Allah's bounty which He specifies for some of His servants. Al-Nawawi said - while listing a number of maladies of students of knowledge -: "Among them is caution against envy, showing off, self-admiration, and looking down on people even if they are degrees below him. These are maladies and diseases with which many of those with vile souls are afflicted. The way to negate envy is to know that the wisdom of Allah Almighty required placing this virtue in this human being; so do not object to nor dislike what Wisdom required" (1). Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Some of those affiliated with knowledge and others may be afflicted with a type of envy towards one whom Allah has guided with beneficial knowledge or righteous deed. This is a blameworthy trait absolutely, and it is in this position among the morals of those who earned anger" (2).
foot_note:
1. Al-Majmu' Sharh Al-Muhadhdhab (1/28).
2. Iqtida' Al-Sirat Al-Mustaqim (1/83).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Complaints about the envy of some people of knowledge towards others have been ancient. A group of people of knowledge envied Al-Shafi'i, so Ahmad said defending Al-Shafi'i: "By Allah, we have seen nothing from him but good, nor heard anything but good. Then Ahmad said to those around him: Know - may Allah Almighty have mercy on you - that a man among the people of knowledge, if Allah grants him something of knowledge and his peers and likes are deprived of it, they envy him and accuse him of what is not in him. What a miserable trait in the people of knowledge" (1). Let the student of knowledge beware of speaking about his peers inappropriately, and let not Satan enter upon him and blow into the fire of envy between him and his companions among the students of knowledge; rather, let him strive against himself in that. Al-Dhahabi said in the biography of Mutayyan (2): "Muhammad bin Uthman bin Abi Shaybah (3) spoke against him, and he spoke against Ibn Uthman. The speech of peers is generally not considered, especially if there is competition between them. Ibn Uthman counted about three delusions for Mutayyan, so what? Mutayyan is the more trustworthy of the two men, and the commendation of someone like Al-Daraqutni suffices him" (4).
foot_note:

2. He is Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Sulaiman Al-Hadrami Al-Kufi, nicknamed and known as (Mutayyan). 3. He is Al-Hafiz Abu Ja'far Muhammad bin Uthman bin Abi Shaybah Al-Kufi Al-Absi by loyalty. He had many Hadiths and broad narration. Among his works is Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir. He died in the year (297 AH). See his biography: Tarikh Baghdad (4/68), and Tadhkirat Al-Huffaz (2/171).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Second: Not being stingy in benefiting and helping them: Based on the generality of Allah's saying: {And cooperate in righteousness and piety, but do not cooperate in sin and aggression} [Al-Ma'idah: 2]. Meaning: Let some of you help others in righteousness. Righteousness: A comprehensive name for everything Allah loves and is pleased with, of outward and inward deeds, regarding the rights of Allah and the rights of humans... And every trait of good ordered to be done, or trait of evil ordered to be left, the servant is commanded to do it himself, and to help others among his believing brothers in it (1). Among the virtues regarding the student of knowledge: That he strives to convey what he has learned to his colleagues, and exerts effort in informing them, and does not withhold (2) from them what he has; for withholding what he has and stinginess in it is a sign of selfishness and evidence of weak faith restraint. The requirement of faith and brotherhood is to love for his brother what he loves for himself; based on what Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated from the Prophet, peace be upon him, who said: "None of you [truly] believes until he loves for his brother what he loves for himself" (3). Third: Reviewing knowledge together: It is beautiful for a student of knowledge to recall knowledge and its issues with his companions, reviving the sunnah of the early predecessors, and practicing dialogue and discussion with his comrades to establish knowledge in his mind, thereby strengthening his memorization and recall, and knowing the places of his errors

text: and areas of defect, and benefiting from what others have. Al-Khalil bin Ahmad said: "Discuss your knowledge; you will remember what you have, and benefit from what you do not have" (1). Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi titled two chapters in his collection on this: Chapter One: "Chapter on Discussion with Followers and Companions" (2), and Chapter Two: "Chapter on Discussion with Peers and Equals" (3). On the authority of Muslim Al-Batin, he said: "I saw Abu Yahya Al-A'raj - who was knowledgeable in the hadith of Ibn Abbas - he and Sa'id bin Jubayr gathered in the mosque of Kufa, and discussed the hadith of Ibn Abbas" (4). Ibrahim Al-Nakhai said: "The night feels long to me, until I meet my companions and discuss with them" (5). On the authority of Abu Mushir, he said: "I heard Sa'id bin Abd al-Aziz scolding the companions of Al-Awza'i, saying: Why do you not gather? Why do you not discuss together?!" (6).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Type Four: The Student's Etiquette with the General Public: There are a number of etiquettes that a student of knowledge should embody in his dealings with people, which are: First: Teaching them and offering advice to them: The responsibility of the student of knowledge before people is a great responsibility, especially if they are his family, relatives, and clan. Allah Almighty said: {And warn your closest kindred} [Ash-Shu'ara: 214]. And He Glory be to Him said: {O you who have believed, protect yourselves and your families from a Fire whose fuel is people and stones} [At-Tahrim: 6]. And Allah Almighty said: {And it is not for the believers to go forth [to battle] all at once. For there should separate from every division of them a group [remaining] to obtain understanding in the religion and warn their people when they return to them that they might be cautious} [At-Tawbah: 122]. "Meaning to learn Sharia knowledge, know its meanings, understand its secrets, teach others, and warn their people when they return to them. In this is the virtue of knowledge, especially understanding in religion, and that it is the most important of matters, and that whoever learns knowledge must spread and disseminate it among the servants, and advise them in it, for the spread of knowledge from the scholar is from his blessing and his reward which grows for him" (1).
foot_note: 1. Tayseer Al-Karim Al-Rahman p. (355).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Second: To speak to people about what they know: One of the things a student of knowledge must pay attention to in his call to the general public is to address them with what they understand and comprehend, and not to address them with something their minds cannot grasp, nor understand; because that calls for them to be tempted in their religion, and to understand speech contrary to its intent, so they go astray from where they do not perceive, and it becomes a cause for their misguidance and error (1). Abdullah bin Masud, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "You do not narrate a hadith to a people that their minds do not grasp, except that it becomes a tribulation (fitnah) for some of them" (2). Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Speak to people about what they know. Do you want Allah and His Messenger to be denied?" (3). Al-Bukhari titled this narration: "Chapter: Whoever specified knowledge for a people to the exclusion of others; disliking that they might not understand" (4). "In this narration is that knowledge should be specified for a people because of their retention and correctness of understanding, and the subtle meaning should not be offered to one who does not deserve it among students and one upon whom license and reliance is feared due to his short understanding" (5). Ibn Hubayrah, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "In this hadith is jurisprudence: That the scholar should raise people with knowledge a [proper] upbringing, and feed them it a [proper] feeding; so he raises them with small knowledge before big knowledge,

text: so he becomes a Rabbani (Lordly scholar) as came in the other hadith. This is clarified by the fact that the child, when his stomach was not strong enough to digest coarse foods, Allah facilitated his provision from his mother's breast for a long period in which he gradually moves to consuming foods remaining in their state. For milk was food, then it turned into milk so it became like the rising thing, so it is of the gentlest foods. If the child's stomach becomes strong, he is fed strong foods. Likewise, the scholar should be gentle with people in teaching, so he does not expose their minds to hearing what they deny before he is certain of the strength of their minds to repel suspicion, accept proof, disbelieve in Taghut, and believe in Allah, otherwise he exposes them to denial, as Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Do you want Allah and His Messenger to be denied?" (1). Ibn Hajar, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "And in it is evidence that the ambiguous (Mutashabih) should not be mentioned before the common people" (2). This is the methodology of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them. - This is Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him: It came from him that he said: "I memorized from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, two vessels: As for one of them, I spread it, and as for the other, if I spread it, this pharynx would be cut" (3), and the meaning is what happens of tribulations and the like. - And Al-Hasan, may Allah have mercy on him: Denied Anas's narration to Al-Hajjaj of the story of the Uraniyyin; because he took it as a means to what he relied upon of excess in shedding blood with his flimsy interpretation. - And Abu Yusuf, one of the companions of Abu Hanifa, disliked narrating strange things to people. - And Malik disliked narrating to common people the hadiths of Attributes (4).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Third: Mercy towards them and showing compassion for them: Allah made Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, the role model of creation in mercy and kindness to the believers, and his Lord described him saying: {Concerned over you, to the believers kind and merciful} [At-Tawbah: 128]. Jarir bin Abdullah narrated, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "He who does not show mercy to people, Allah Almighty will not show mercy to him" (1). "So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, encouraged mercy and kindness to all creation of all animals (2), of their various kinds in more than one hadith, and the most noble of them is the human, even if he is (3) a disbeliever. So be merciful to yourself and others, and do not hoard your good. Have mercy on the ignorant with your knowledge, the humiliated with your status, the poor with your money, the old and young with your compassion and kindness, the sinners with your call, and the animals with your kindness. For the closest people to Allah's mercy are those most merciful to His creation" (4). And have mercy with your heart on Allah's creation and tend to them ... For the Most Merciful only has mercy on he who shows mercy. And intend by that the Face of Allah our Creator ... Glory be to Him from a God who created the souls. And seek the reward of that from your Master, His mercy ... Allah does not wrong a servant who was noble.
foot_note:

See: Mafatih Al-Ulum by Al-Khawarizmi p. (166), and Al-Mathal Al-Sa'ir fi Adab Al-Katib wa Al-Sha'ir by Ibn Al-Athir (1/411).
3. In the printed version: (And if he is), and the correct is what we established.

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: Sheikh al-Islam, may Allah have mercy on him, said describing Ahlus-Sunnah: "They are the most knowledgeable of people about the truth, and the most merciful of them to creation" (1). This is the trait of the successful student of knowledge; you find him merciful to people, kind and gentle with them, compassionate towards them and having mercy on them, hoping for their guidance, and striving for their religious and worldly interests. Fourth: Casting Salam (Peace) and returning it, and smiling in the faces of others: Casting Salam and returning it are among the causes of spreading love among Muslims. Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "You will not enter Paradise until you believe, and you will not believe until you love one another. Shall I not guide you to something if you do it you will love one another? Spread Salam amongst yourselves" (2). Indeed, the Prophetic Sunnah came commanding Salam upon everyone: On the authority of Abdullah bin Amr, may Allah be pleased with them: "That a man asked the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, which Islam is best? He said: To feed food, and to read Salam upon whom you know and whom you do not know" (3). This is contrary to what some people are upon, who do not greet except their acquaintances, and this is one of the mistakes in the chapter of Salam. Islam encouraged initiating Salam, and arranged virtues upon it, including: The hadith of Abu Umamah, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed the closest people to Allah are those who begin them with Salam" (4).

book_title: Introduction to the Sciences of Sharia
text: And the hadith of Sayyar bin Abi Sayyar, who said: "I was walking with Thabit Al-Bunani, and he passed by boys and greeted them. Thabit narrated that he was walking with Anas, and he passed by boys and greeted them. Anas narrated that he was walking with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and he passed by boys and greeted them" (1). We benefit from these hadiths: the legitimacy of spreading Salam and casting it upon everyone, even children, because it is part of being kind to them and winning their hearts. As for smiling, it is one of the highest means of winning hearts; rather, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, considered it an act of worship: He said: "Your smile in the face of your brother is charity for you" (2). Al-Tabarani titled a chapter on it: "Chapter: The virtue of a man smiling in the face of his Muslim brother" (3). The guidance of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was smiling without laughing [loudly], as came in the hadith of Jabir bin Samurah who said - while talking about the Companions with the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "They used to talk and take up matters of the Jahiliyyah, so they would laugh and he would smile" (4). The student of knowledge's model and ideal example is his Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. How beautiful is the student of knowledge smiling, cheerful, with a free face. Ibn Uyaynah, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "Cheerfulness is the trap of affection, and righteousness is an easy thing; a cheerful face and gentle speech." Ibn Al-Mubarak, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "I admire from the readers (of Quran/Scholars) every free-faced laughing one, as for...

text: who meets you with cheerfulness, while he meets you with a frown, as if he is conferring a favor upon you with his knowledge; may Allah not increase his likes among the reciters (1). Fifth: Forbearance and Gentleness: Allah Almighty said: {So by mercy from Allah, you were lenient with them. And if you had been rude [in speech] and harsh in heart, they would have disbanded from about you. So pardon them and ask forgiveness for them and consult them in the matter} [Al Imran: 159]. And Allah Almighty says, advising Moses and Aaron: {Go, both of you, to Pharaoh. Indeed, he has transgressed (43) And speak to him with gentle speech that perhaps he may be reminded or fear [Allah]} [Taha: 43, 44]. On the authority of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: Gentleness is not found in anything but that it adorns it, and it is not removed from anything but that it defects it (2). The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, considered the harsh person to be devoid of goodness, saying: Whoever is deprived of gentleness is deprived of goodness (3). If Allah combines knowledge and forbearance for a student of knowledge, He has gathered for him the edges of goodness. On the authority of Abu Razin, regarding His saying: {Be Rabbaniyyin (pious scholars)} [Al Imran: 79]; he said: Forbearing scholars (4). And regarding Al-Hasan, he said: {And when the ignorant address them [harshly], they say [words of] peace} [Al-Furqan: 63]; Forbearing, even if they are treated ignorantly, they do not act ignorantly (5).

Sixth: Not to place himself in a position where knowledge and its people are humiliated: The student of knowledge is a role model for people; he should be in a bright image, for he is the ambassador of knowledge and scholars, reflecting their image and leaving a good impression of them. Therefore, he must distance himself from everything that scratches this beautiful image and challenges this vision, whether in terms of his essence or appearance, his speech or his actions. Among this is: First: Care for appropriate clothing: The predecessors (Salaf) used to care about clothing and good appearance. Yahya bin Muhammad Al-Shahid, may Allah have mercy on him, said: I have not seen a narrator more pious than Yahya bin Yahya, nor one with better clothing than him (3). Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said: Renew (4) the clothes when you wear them, for they are... The adornment of men, by which you are honored and respected.

text: And leave humility in clothes out of sin/piety... For Allah knows what you conceal and hide. For the shabbiness of your garment does not increase your nearness... To Allah while you are a sinful servant. And the splendor of your garment does not harm you after you... Fear Allah and avoid what is forbidden (1). It is also recommended for the student of knowledge to take care of himself in terms of cleanliness, bathing, perfuming, and removing unpleasant odors. Al-Nawawi said - speaking about the etiquette of the student of knowledge when entering gatherings of knowledge -: And he should enter with full dignity, his heart empty of distractions, purified, cleaned with Siwak (toothstick), trimming the mustache and nails, and removing unpleasant odors (2). Seventh: Distancing from gatherings of idle talk and clamor: The gatherings that the student of knowledge attends and gains knowledge and reward by attending are gatherings of knowledge, jurisprudence, and etiquette. He distances himself from gatherings of falsehood and amusement, where gossip, backbiting, tale-bearing, obscenity, immorality, shameless stories, mocking religion and its people, and ridiculing them abound; indeed, explicit disbelief might occur therein, and refuge is sought with Allah Almighty. Allah Almighty said: {And those who do not testify to falsehood, and when they pass near ill speech, they pass by with dignity} [Al-Furqan: 72]. The meaning of the verse: Meaning: They do not attend falsehood, meaning: forbidden speech and action. So they avoid all gatherings containing forbidden words or forbidden actions, such as delving into

2. Al-Majmu' Sharh Al-Muhadhdhab (1/ 36).

text: the verses of Allah, false argument, backbiting, tale-bearing, cursing, slander, mockery, forbidden singing, drinking alcohol, spreading silk [carpets for men], images, and the like. If they do not witness falsehood, then it is even more appropriate that they do not say or do it (1). The Almighty said: {And it has already come down to you in the Book that when you hear the verses of Allah [recited], they are denied [by them] and ridiculed; so do not sit with them until they enter into another conversation. Indeed, you would then be like them} [An-Nisa: 140]. The summary of the matter: You, O student of knowledge, must not tread on the carpet of those who commit evil in their club, and tear the veils of etiquette, feigning ignorance of that. If you do that, your crime against knowledge and its people is great (2). Eighth: Distancing from commotion (Haishat) and Fitnah (sedition): The student of knowledge must beware of places of recklessness, commotion, and sedition which are populated by those of light minds and bad manners, because they cause knowledge to lose its beauty and prestige. On the authority of Abdullah bin Masoud, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: Beware of the commotions (Haishat) of the markets (3). And the commotions of the markets: meaning their mixing and what occurs in them of trials and raised voices. He wanted them not to be of their people, for correctness is hidden therein, the truth is not clear therein, and every person deserving of delay is advanced therein, and every person deserving of advancement is delayed therein (4).

text: Sheikh Bakr Abu Zayd, may Allah have mercy on him, said in the book Al-Hilyah: (Turning away from commotions), then he advised: Protecting oneself from clamor and commotions, for error is under the clamor, and this contradicts the etiquette of seeking [knowledge] (1). Conclusion: The student of knowledge should adorn himself with the etiquettes of the soul; such as chastity, forbearance, patience, and humility to the truth. He should adopt the stillness of a bird: dignity, gravity, and lowering the wing (humility); bearing the humiliation of learning for the glory of knowledge and the nobility of its goal. O student of knowledge, beware of the nullifiers of these etiquettes, for along with sin, they establish against yourself a witness that there is a defect in the mind, and indicate deprivation of success. Beware of pride (Al-Khuyala'), for it is hypocrisy and arrogance, and the severity of guarding against it among the predecessors reached a great extent and a far limit (2). These are fragments on the etiquette of the student of knowledge with himself, with his sheikh, with his brothers and colleagues, and with all people. May Allah grant us all success to adhere to these etiquettes, adorn ourselves with them, and act upon them.

text: Methodology of the Student of Knowledge in Seeking Knowledge: After mentioning the etiquette of the student of knowledge, it is worth explaining the sound methodology that the student of knowledge should follow, which is represented in the following: First: Mastering the Fundamentals (Usul): (Whoever does not master the fundamentals; is denied arrival), and (Whoever seeks knowledge in a lump sum, it goes away from him in a lump sum), and it was also said: (Crowding knowledge in the hearing is a misleading of understanding). Therefore, there must be rooting and founding for every art you seek, by mastering its original text and its summary with a proficient sheikh, not by self-acquisition alone. Take knowledge gradually, for it is the path to firmness. Allah Almighty said: {And [it is] a Qur'an which We have separated [by intervals] that you might recite it to the people over a prolonged period. And We have sent it down progressively} [Al-Isra: 106]. So Allah Almighty commanded in this verse to take the Quran over a prolonged period and deliberately. Thus, taking knowledge and acquiring it should be likewise. So before you are matters that must be observed in every art you seek: 1 - Memorizing a summary in it. 2 - Mastering it with a proficient sheikh. 3 - Mastering its explanation. 4 - Reviewing what you have memorized and mastered its explanation constantly; for repeating knowledge is the guarantee of its stability. Second: Receiving knowledge from Sheikhs: The origin in seeking is through dictation and receiving from Sheikhs, and taking from the mouths of men, not from newspapers and the bellies of books.
foot_note: None

text: It has been said: (Whoever enters into knowledge alone; exits alone); meaning: whoever enters into seeking knowledge without a sheikh; exits from it without knowledge. This statement, although not precise, contains much truth. Third: Preserving knowledge by writing: Exert effort in preserving knowledge by writing it; because binding knowledge by writing is a security against loss, especially in issues of knowledge that are not in their expected places. Among its greatest benefits is that in old age and weakness of strength, you will have material to draw from and write in without the trouble of research and investigation. Al-Sha'bi said: If you hear something, write it down, even if on a wall (1). Fourth: Maintaining what is memorized: Maintain your knowledge from time to time, for lack of maintenance is the title of the departure of knowledge, whatever it may be. On the authority of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: The example of the companion of the Quran is only like the example of the companion of the hobbled camels; if he tends to them, he keeps them, and if he releases them, they go away (2). Al-Hafiz Ibn Abd Al-Barr, may Allah have mercy on him, said: In this Hadith is evidence that whoever does not tend to his knowledge, it goes away from him (3). If the Quran, which is made easy for remembrance, goes away if not tended to, what do you think of other customary sciences?!.
