text: Fifth: Resorting to Allah Almighty in seeking and acquisition: Do not be sad if a science is not opened to you. Double the desire, and flee to Allah in supplication, resorting to Him, and breaking down before Him. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, often said in his supplication if the interpretation of a verse from the Book of Allah Almighty became difficult for him: "O Teacher of Adam and Abraham, teach me; and O One who gave understanding to Solomon, give me understanding," and he would find the opening in that. Sixth: Do not be 'Abu Shibr' (Father of a Span): This is by claiming knowledge of what you do not know, or mastery of what you have not mastered. If you do, it is a thick veil against knowledge. Beware of being (Abu Shibr), for it has been said: Knowledge is three spans. Whoever enters the first span becomes arrogant, whoever enters the second span becomes humble, and whoever enters the third span knows that he does not know. Seventh: Preserving the hours of your life: O student of knowledge, Time, time for acquisition... So preserving time with seriousness and diligence, sticking to the quest, keeping close company with Sheikhs, and occupying oneself with knowledge by reading, teaching, studying, contemplating, memorizing, and researching, especially in the prime of youth and the beginning of life, and the mine of the outcome. So seize this precious opportunity; to attain the high ranks of knowledge, for it is (a time of gathering the heart and concentration of thought); due to the lack of distractions and diversions from life obligations and leadership, and the lightness of burdens and dependents (1).
foot_note: 1. Hilyat Talib Al-Ilm p. (184).

text: Eighth: Eagerness for beneficial sciences: Be eager for what benefits you and brings you closer to Allah among the sciences; for sciences are many and times are scarce. The successful one is he who occupies himself with what deepens his connection with Allah and increases his faith and attachment to his Master. For this reason, among the supplications of our Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was that he used to ask Allah for beneficial knowledge, as proven in the Hadith of Umm Salamah - may Allah be pleased with her: That the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say: When he prayed the morning prayer, upon giving Salams: O Allah, I ask You for beneficial knowledge, good provision, and acceptable deeds (1). The signs of beneficial knowledge are: 1) Acting upon the knowledge. 2) Increase in faith and abundance of acts of obedience. 3) Dislike of self-praise and commendation. 4) That your humility increases whenever your knowledge increases. 5) Fleeing from the love of leadership, fame, and appearance. 6) Abandoning the claim of knowledge. 7) Thinking ill of oneself, and thinking well of people to avoid falling into [badmouthing] them. 8) Spreading knowledge, and doing good to people by offering it, and seeking reward from Allah for that.

text:
Section Two
A Brief Overview of Sharia Sciences
foot_note: None

text: Sharia sciences are the sciences derived from Islamic Sharia and its two main sources: the Holy Quran and the Noble Sunnah. It applies to Tafsir (Exegesis) and Quranic sciences, Prophetic Hadith and its sciences, the science of Aqidah (Creed), and Fiqh (Jurisprudence), its principles, and rules. These Sharia sciences are the most noble sciences absolutely, due to the honor of their connection to the two revelations: the Book and the Sunnah. They are the most deserving of what times, money, and efforts are spent on. It is not hidden from anyone with intellect that acquiring these sciences is obligatory on every accountable person, to the extent that ensures his worship of Allah Almighty in the manner prescribed. This is what is known as 'Necessary Knowledge' (Al-Ma'lum min al-din bid-darura), by which rulings are known and acted upon, whether for males or females, since a person's need to reform his religion and purify his soul is no less than his need for food, drink, and other necessities of life. There is no doubt that knowledge is honor, light, and virtue, just as ignorance is evil, affliction, and vice. Beneficial knowledge is the source and spring of virtues, while ignorance is the ambush of vices and their path. Therefore, the highest people in rank, the greatest in status, and the most elevated in position are the people of knowledge of Allah and His Messenger: {Allah will raise those who have believed among you and those who were given knowledge, by degrees} [Al-Mujadila: 11]. So the most worthy thing for competitors to compete in, and the most appropriate thing for racers to race towards, is what guarantees the servant's happiness in his livelihood and hereafter, and is a guide to the path of this happiness. That is beneficial knowledge and righteous deeds, without which there is no happiness for the servant, and no salvation for him except by clinging to their cause. So whoever is blessed with knowledge and action has succeeded and gained, and whoever is deprived of knowledge and action is deprived of all good.
foot_note: None

text: Therefore, Allah honored the people of knowledge and made them witness to His Oneness and His uniqueness in worship and divinity, as He Almighty said: {Allah witnesses that there is no deity except Him, and [so do] the angels and those of knowledge - [that He is] maintaining [creation] in justice. There is no deity except Him, the Exalted in Might, the Wise} [Al Imran: 18]. And for the people of knowledge, Allah facilitates the easiest paths to Paradise, and the inhabitants of the heavens and the earth, even the fish in the sea, ask forgiveness for them, as proven in the Hadith of Abu Darda on the authority of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: Whoever follows a path seeking knowledge therein, Allah will pave for him a path to Paradise. Indeed, the angels lower their wings in approval of the student of knowledge. And indeed, the scholar, those in the heavens and those on earth ask forgiveness for him, even the fish in the water. The superiority of the scholar over the worshiper is like the superiority of the moon on the night of the full moon over all other stars. Indeed, the scholars are the heirs of the Prophets, and the Prophets did not leave behind a Dinar or a Dirham, but they left behind knowledge. So whoever takes it has taken an abundant share (1). Through knowledge, laws and rulings are known, and the lawful is distinguished from the prohibited. Knowledge is the leader (Imam) and action is the follower (Ma'mum); it is a commander and action is a subordinate. Revising knowledge is glorification (Tasbih), searching for it is Jihad, seeking it is an act of closeness to Allah Almighty, giving it is charity, and studying knowledge is equivalent to fasting and night prayer. The need for it is greater than the need for drink and food. Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, said: People are more in need of knowledge than they are of food and drink; because food and drink are needed once or twice a day, but knowledge is needed

This is how Mahmoud bin Khadash told us with this chain. This Hadith is [also] narrated from Asim bin Raja' bin Haywah, from Al-Walid bin Jamil, from Kathir bin Qais, from Abu Darda, from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and this is more correct than the Hadith of Mahmoud bin Khadash, and Muhammad bin Ismail's opinion is this is more correct.

text: at every moment (1). For this reason, knowing knowledge and action was one of the most obligatory duties upon servants, by which is their salvation and happiness in this world and the Hereafter. A very important warning must be given to the student of knowledge: Knowledge is the greatest worship, and Allah has not been worshipped with anything greater than knowledge. Acting upon knowledge is the fruit of knowledge and cognition. Knowledge is like the tree and acting upon it is its fruit. Whoever acts upon what he knows, Allah Almighty bequeaths him knowledge of what he did not know, as He Almighty said: {And if We had decreed upon them, "Kill yourselves" or "Leave your homes," they would not have done it, except for a few of them. But if they had done what they were instructed, it would have been better for them and a firmer position [for them in faith]. (66) And then We would have given them from Us a great reward. (67) And We would have guided them to a straight path} [An-Nisa: 66-68]. So whoever Allah wants good, happiness, salvation, and high status for in this world and the Hereafter, He facilitates for him beneficial knowledge and righteous deeds, as proven in the two Sahihs from the Hadith of Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: Whomever Allah wills good for, He gives him understanding in the religion (2). Ibn Hajar, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The implication of the Hadith is that whoever does not gain understanding in religion, meaning does not learn the rules of Islam and the branches connected to them, has been deprived of good; because whoever does not know the matters of his religion is neither a Faqih (jurist) nor a student of Fiqh, so it is valid to describe him as one for whom

Here, O student of knowledge, is a brief overview of the Sharia sciences, their categories, and the most prominent terms of each art:

text: First: The Science of Tafsir (Exegesis): The science of Tafsir occupies the forefront among Sharia sciences; because understanding the meanings of the Quran is a necessary matter for the reader of the Quran and the one seeking understanding in religion. The science of Tafsir is one of the most important sciences that a student of knowledge should care for, since the honor of a science is by the honor of the known subject. Reflect on what Sheikh Al-Islam said at the end of his life when he regretted not dedicating most of his time to the Quran. He said, may Allah have mercy on him: Allah has opened for me in this time, from the meanings of the Quran and from the principles of knowledge, things that many scholars would wish for, and I regretted wasting most of my time on other than the meanings of the Quran (1). Definition of Tafsir: Tafsir linguistically: A noun derived from 'Fassara' - with the doubling of the Sin - taken from 'Al-Fasr': which is uncovering, clarification, and explanation. From that is His saying Almighty: {And they do not come to you with an argument except that We bring you the truth and the best explanation (Tafsira)} [Al-Furqan: 33]. Technically: A science by which the understanding of the Book of Allah Almighty revealed to Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, is known, and the clarification of its meanings, and the extraction of its rulings and wisdoms. Divisions of Tafsir: The science of Tafsir varies according to the consideration upon which it was divided; because Tafsir has several divisions based on different considerations. The most important of these divisions is dividing it according to the trends of the commentators (Mufassirin). According to this consideration, it can be divided into three sections:
foot_note: 1. Quoted by Ibn Abd Al-Hadi in Al-Uqud Al-Durriyyah p. (44), and Ibn Rajab in Dhayl Tabaqat Al-Hanabilah (4/ 519).

text: First: Tafsir bi-al-Ma'thur (Interpretation by Tradition/Narration): It is the one that relies on interpreting the Quran by the Quran, or by the Sunnah; or by what was narrated from the Companions; or by what the senior Followers (Tabi'in) said. It is the best section of Tafsir, if it is free from weak Hadiths and Israelite narrations (Isra'iliyyat). Among the books of Tafsir bi-al-Ma'thur: 1) Jami' al-Bayan, by Abu Ja'far Muhammad bin Jarir al-Tabari, died in the year (310 AH). 2) Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim, by Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Hatim, died in the year (327 AH). 3) Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim, by Ismail bin Umar bin Kathir, died in the year (774 AH). Second: Tafsir bi-al-Ra'y wal-Ijtihad (Interpretation by Opinion and Reasoning/Knowledge): This section is of two types: Permissible and Blameworthy. As for the Permissible: It is striving (Ijtihad) to interpret what has no established transmitted text or narrated tradition, according to known conditions. As for the Blameworthy, it is the opposite of that. Like commentaries written to support innovations in beliefs, or commentaries that have no sound basis. Among the books of Tafsir bi-al-Ra'y: 1) Mafatih al-Ghayb, by Muhammad bin Umar Fakhr al-Din al-Razi, died in the year (606 AH). 2) Anwar al-Tanzil, by Abdullah bin Umar al-Baydawi, died in the year (685 AH). 3) Lubab al-Ta'wil, by Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Muhammad al-Khazin, died in the year (741 AH). Third: Al-Tafsir Al-Ishari (Indicative Interpretation): It is interpreting the Quran unlike its apparent meaning for a hidden sign that the Batinis and Sufis believe appears to them. This section of Tafsir is rejected and invalid.
foot_note: None

text: Among the books of Tafsir Al-Ishari: 1) Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim, by Sahl bin Abdullah al-Tustari, died in the year (283 AH). 2) Haqa'iq al-Tafsir, by Muhammad bin al-Husayn al-Sulami, died in the year (412 AH). 3) Al-Bahr al-Madid, by Ahmad bin Muhammad Ibn Ajiba, died in the year (1224 AH). Among the sciences upon which the interpretation of the Quran is based: What is known as Sciences of the Quran (Ulum al-Quran): It refers to the group of sciences whose topics relate specifically to the Holy Quran, whether concerning its revelation, arrangement, collection, writing or drawing, recitation, parsing (I'rab), interpretation, miraculous nature (I'jaz), abrogating and abrogated verses, Meccan and Medinan verses, or refuting doubts about it, etc. The fruit of studying the science of Tafsir and its benefits: Studying the science of Tafsir has many fruits and benefits, including: 1) Filling people's need to understand the Quran, live with it, and achieve happiness through it. 2) Understanding the divine legal discourse, and knowing the rulings, the lawful, and the prohibited. 3) It helps the servant to contemplate the Book of Allah. Ibn Jarir al-Tabari said: I wonder at one who recites the Quran and does not know its interpretation, how he finds pleasure in reading it (1). 4) Understanding the origin and development of the science of Tafsir, and the efforts of the Companions, Followers, and scholars after them in serving the interpretation of the Holy Quran, what distinguished each effort, and how to benefit from it in broadening the comprehension of the meanings of the Holy Quran and standing upon its great secrets.
foot_note: 1. See: Mu'jam Al-Udaba (6/ 2453).

text: 5) Knowing the sound methodology and correct ways to interpret the Holy Quran, in a way that observes the rules and regulations of the predecessors, and keeps pace with the spirit of our age and its requirements. 6) Knowing the doctrinal, jurisprudential, theological, and linguistic trends of the commentators, and how these diverse trends enriched the library of Tafsir in its different eras. 7) Standing upon the greatness of the Book of Allah which received this immense amount of care and attention, which earns the servant veneration for the Book of Allah, and fear of the One who revealed it and spoke it, Glory be to Him. Terminology of the Science of Tafsir: The Quran: Is the miraculous Arabic phrasing, revealed to Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, through Gabriel, peace be upon him, which is transmitted by recurrence (Tawatur), written in the Mushaf, worshipped by its recitation, beginning with Surah Al-Fatiha, and ending with Surah An-Nas. The Science of Tafsir: Is a science by which the understanding of the Book of Allah Almighty revealed to Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, is known, and the clarification of its meanings and extraction of its rulings and wisdoms. Sciences of the Quran: Are topics related to the Holy Quran in terms of its revelation, arrangement, collection, writing, readings, decisive and ambiguous verses, abrogating and abrogated verses, miraculous nature, styles, and refuting doubts about it... etc. Meccan Quran: Is everything revealed of the Quran before the Prophetic Migration (Hijra), even if its revelation was outside Mecca. Medinan Quran: Is everything revealed after the Prophetic Migration, even if its revelation was in Mecca.
foot_note: None

text: Reason for Revelation (Sabab al-Nuzul): Is the incident or question following which the verse or Surah was revealed as an explanation for it. It is either an incident that occurs so the Quran is revealed because of it, or a question addressed to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, so the Quran is revealed clarifying the ruling on it. Isra'iliyyat: Are the news narrated from the People of the Book, Jews or Christians. They were called (Isra'iliyyat) by predominance, because most of them are from the news of the Children of Israel or from their books. Decisive Verses (Ayat Muhkamat): Are the verses with clear meaning that do not bear more than one facet of interpretation. Ambiguous Verses (Ayat Mutashabihat): Are the verses that bear more than one facet of interpretation. Readings (Qira'at): Plural of Qira'ah, which is a school of thought adopted by one of the Imams of the Reciters, differing from others in pronunciation of the Holy Quran, with agreement of narrations and paths from him. Abrogation (Naskh): Is the lifting of a legal ruling by another legal evidence that comes after it. Abrogated Verses (Ayat Mansukha): Are of three types: 1) Verses whose recitation and ruling were abrogated. Example: Abrogation of prohibition of breastfeeding from ten sucklings to five. On the authority of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: Among what was revealed of the Quran was: Ten known sucklings prohibit [marriage], then they were abrogated by five known ones. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, passed away, and they were among what is recited of the Quran (1). 2) Verses whose ruling was abrogated but their recitation remained, and this is the most common type of abrogation.
foot_note: 1. Narrated by Muslim in his Sahih (2/ 1075) No. (1452).

text: Example: Abrogation of the waiting period for the widow from a full year to four months and ten days. Allah Almighty said: {And those who are taken in death among you and leave wives behind - for their wives is a bequest: maintenance for one year without turning [them] out} ... [Al-Baqarah: 240]. Then that was abrogated by His saying: {And those who are taken in death among you and leave wives behind - they, [the wives, shall] wait four months and ten [days]} [Al-Baqarah: 234]. 3) Verses whose recitation was abrogated but their ruling remained. Example: The verse of Stoning The old man and the old woman, if they commit adultery, stone them absolutely, its recitation was abrogated but its ruling remained. Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: Indeed, Allah sent Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, with the truth, and revealed the Book to him. Among what was revealed to him was the verse of Stoning. We read it and understood it. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stoned, and we stoned after him. I feared that if time passed long for people, someone might say: We do not find the verse of Stoning in the Book of Allah, so they would go astray by abandoning a duty revealed by Allah Almighty. Stoning is a right upon whoever commits adultery among men and women if he is married (Muhsan), if evidence is established, or there is pregnancy, or confession. By Allah, were it not that people would say: Umar added to the Book of Allah Almighty, I would have written it: The old man and the old woman, if they commit adultery, stone them absolutely (1). These are the most important and prominent terms related to Tafsir.
foot_note: 1. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (8/ 168) No. (6829), Muslim (3/ 1317) No. (1691), and Abu Dawood (4/ 144) No. (4418), and the wording is his.

text: Second: Hadith and its Sciences: The science of Hadith is among the most noble and majestic sciences, after the knowledge of the Holy Quran which is the origin of religion and the source of the straight path. Hadith is the second source of Islamic legislation; some of it legislates independently, and much of it explains the Book of Allah Almighty and clarifies it. Allah Almighty said: {And We revealed to you the message that you may make clear to the people what was sent down to them} [An-Nahl: 44]. Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said: The science of Hadith is of serious impact, great benefit; upon it revolves most rulings, and by it the lawful and prohibited are known. Its people have terminology that the student must understand (1). Definition of Hadith: Hadith linguistically: The new (Al-Jadid), opposite of old (Al-Qadim). From it is his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding rain: It has recently been with its Lord (Hadithu Ahdin bi-Rabbihi) (2) i.e., new. It also refers to news (Al-Khabar). Al-Firuzabadi said: Al-Hadith: The new, and the news. From it is His saying Almighty: {Has there come to you the story (Hadith) of Moses?} [Taha: 9] i.e., news of Moses. Technically: What is attributed to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, of saying, action, approval, or physical or moral description.
foot_note:
1. Sharh Al-Tabsirah (1/ 97). 
2. Narrated by Muslim in his Sahih (2/ 615) No. (898).

text: Divisions of the Science of Hadith: Generally, the science of Hadith is divided into two sections: 1 - The Science of Hadith Narration (Riwayah): It is a science that investigates how Hadiths are connected to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, in terms of the conditions of their narrators regarding precision and integrity, and in terms of the nature of the chain (Sanad) regarding connection, disconnection, etc. 2 - The Science of Hadith Understanding (Dirayah): It is a science related to the jurisprudence of Hadith and what pertains to it regarding knowing the abrogating and abrogated, and the specific and general. It can be divided in detail into: 1) Science of Terminology (Mustalah): A science by which the condition of the narrator and the narrated is known in terms of acceptance and rejection. 2) Science of Extraction (Takhrij): A science specialized in indicating the location of the Hadith in its original sources from the books of Sunnah and presenting it to people with a statement of the Hadith's rank when needed. 3) Science of Men (Rijal/Jarh wa Ta'dil): It is the science of the conditions of Hadith narrators in terms of acceptance and rejection. 4) Science of Hidden Defects (Ilal): It is the science that critiques the Hadiths of trustworthy narrators in which an illusion or hidden error occurred, and it is one of the most precise and difficult sciences. Fruit of studying the science of Hadith and its benefits: 1) Knowing the status of the Sunnah, which is the second source of legislation, and it explains the Quran; and details its generalities.
foot_note: None

text: 2) Preserving the Islamic religion from distortion and alteration. The Ummah transmitted the Prophetic Hadith with chains of transmission (Asanid), and distinguished by it the authentic from the sick. Were it not for this science, the authentic Hadith would have been confused with the weak and fabricated, the speech of the Messenger would have mixed with the speech of others, and the sciences of Sharia and rulings of religion would have been lost. 3) Knowing the methods of scholars and Muhaddithin in establishing Hadith and purifying it from intruders, through the disciplined scales and majestic rules they established that combine sound methodology and scientific integrity. 4) That the rules of this science protect the scholar from the danger of the great threat that befalls those who are lenient in narrating Hadith, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, in the widespread Hadith from him: Whoever narrates from me a Hadith which he sees is a lie, then he is one of the liars (1), and his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, in the Mutawatir Hadith: Whoever lies about me intentionally, let him take his seat in the Fire (2). 5) That this science earns its possessors a great benefit in clearing minds and precise observation in knowing the authentic Hadith from the sick, and distinguishing what is valid from what is not. 6) This science opens the way for researchers to investigate the meanings of texts (Mutun) and realize their contents, then feel reassured in using them as evidence in all different sciences. 7) Knowing the conditions of Hadith narrators and their classes. 8) Knowing the method of extracting (Takhrij) Hadiths and verifying their chains.

text: 9) The science of Hadith extends its influence to other Islamic sciences. Terminology of the Science of Hadith: Mutawatir (Mass Transmitted): What is narrated by a large number from a large number such that custom or reason deems it impossible for them to collude on a lie. Ahad (Solitary): What lacks a condition of the conditions of Mutawatir. Hadith Qudsi (Divine Hadith): What the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, narrates from his Lord Almighty in wording or meaning, other than the Quran. Marfu' (Elevated) Hadith: What is attributed to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, of saying, action, approval, or description. Mawquf (Stopped) Hadith: What is attributed to the Companion of saying, action, or approval, whether connected or disconnected. Maqtu' (Severed) Hadith: What is attributed to the Followers (Tabi'in) and those below them, stopped at them, of their sayings and actions. Sahih Li-dhatihi (Authentic by itself): What has a connected chain by the transmission of a just, perfectly precise narrator from his like until its end, without anomaly (Shudhudh) or defect (Illah). Sahih Li-ghayrihi (Authentic due to others): It is the Hasan Li-dhatihi Hadith if it is narrated from another path similar to it or stronger than it. Hasan Li-dhatihi (Good by itself): It is the Hadith whose chain is connected by the transmission of a just narrator whose precision is light, without anomaly or defect.
foot_note: None

text: Hasan Li-ghayrihi (Good due to others): It is the Weak Hadith if its paths are multiple and it can be strengthened by another. Da'if (Weak) Hadith: It is the Hadith that lacks a condition of the conditions of the Accepted Hadith, and falls short of the rank of Hasan. Mawdu' (Fabricated) Hadith: It is the falsely invented report attributed to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, falsely. Matruk (Abandoned) Hadith: It is the Hadith in whose chain is a narrator accused of lying, and the Hadith is not known except through him. Shadh (Anomalous) Hadith: What a trustworthy narrator narrates contradicting one who is more trustworthy than him. Munkar (Denounced) Hadith: What a weak narrator narrates contradicting a trustworthy one. Mudraj (Interpolated) Hadith: What is changed in the context of its chain or inserted into its text what is not part of it. Mudtarib (Disordered) Hadith: It is the Hadith narrated in different ways that cannot be reconciled, and it is not possible to combine them. Musahhaf (Distorted) Hadith: It is changing a word in the Hadith from its correct form to another. Muttasil (Connected) Hadith: It is that from whose chain none of its narrators has fallen, whether elevated (Marfu') or stopped (Mawquf). Munqati' (Broken): It is what has fallen from its chain before the Companion, one narrator or more, not consecutively.
foot_note: None

text: Mu'allaq (Suspended) Hadith: What has one or more narrators deleted from the beginning of its chain consecutively, or the entire chain is deleted, or the entire chain is deleted except the Companion. Mu'dal (Perplexing/Double Broken): It is what has two or more narrators fallen from its chain consecutively. Mursal (Hurried): What the Follower (Tabi'i), whether minor or major, elevates to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, by saying: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said. Or it is: What has fallen from the end of its chain after the Follower. Mudallas (Obfuscated): It is of two types: First: Tadlis of the Chain: It is for the narrator to narrate from someone he met what he did not hear from him, creating the illusion that he heard it from him. Second: Tadlis of the Sheikhs: It is for the narrator to narrate a Hadith from a Sheikh he heard from, so he names him, or gives him a Kunya, or attributes him, or describes him with what he is not known by; so that he is not recognized due to his weakness or youth or the like. Mursal Khafi (Hidden Mursal): It is the Hadith that a narrator narrates from someone he was contemporary with but did not meet. These are the most prominent terms related to the science of Hadith.
foot_note: None

text: Third: The Science of Aqidah (Creed): The science of Aqidah is the science that researches Islamic belief and clarifies what opposes and contradicts it. It is derived from the two revelations: the Book and the Sunnah, and clarifies the approach of the Imams of the Ummah from the Companions and Followers, may Allah be pleased with them, in their dealing with issues of belief. The science of Aqidah is the root of sciences; because a person's safety in his religion depends on the soundness of his creed. Islamic Aqidah, when used generally, is the creed of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah; because it is the Islam that Allah was pleased with as a religion for His servants, and it is the creed of the three favored generations of the Companions, the Followers, and those who followed them in goodness until the Day of Judgment. Everything that contradicts the creed of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah is from false beliefs, and its holder has deviated from the correct belief to deviant heretical beliefs. The intended meaning of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah: Everyone who followed the Sunnah of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and held fast to it in word, deed, and belief. Definition of Aqidah: Aqidah linguistically: Taken from Al-'Aqd (tying), which is tightening, binding, firmness, and consolidation. It is said: He tied ('Aqada) the rope, tying it ('Ya'qiduhu'): he tightened it. And 'Al-'Aqd' is the opposite of dissolving. Aqidah is applied to firm faith that is not infiltrated by doubt. It is what a person believes in and ties his heart to. If what he believes is a correct, firm belief in the Lordship of Allah Almighty, His Divinity, His Names and Attributes, His Angels, His Books, His Messengers, the Last Day, Destiny - its good and its evil, and all that is proven of the matters of the Unseen,
foot_note: None

text: and the fundamentals of religion, and what the Righteous Predecessors (Salaf) agreed upon, and complete submission to Allah Almighty in command, judgment, and obedience, and following His Messenger, then this is the correct Salafi Creed. And if what he believes is contrary to that, it is a corrupt creed. Divisions of Aqidah: The division of Aqidah is taken from the six pillars of Faith (Iman), which are: 1) Belief in Allah: It includes: (Belief in His existence, His Lordship, His Divinity, and His Names and Attributes). 2) Belief in the Angels: It includes: (Belief in their existence, belief in those whose names we know among them, belief in what we know of their attributes, and belief in what we know of their actions). 3) Belief in the Revealed Books: It includes: (Belief that their revelation is truly from Allah, belief in those whose names we know among them such as the Quran, the Torah, the Gospel, and the Psalms, along with confirming what is authentic of their news, and acting upon the rulings of what has not been abrogated among them). 4) Belief in the Messengers: It includes: (Belief that their message is truth from Allah, belief in those whose names we know among them by name, along with confirming what is authentic from them of their news, and acting upon the law of the one sent to us among them, who is their seal, Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him.
foot_note: None

text: 5) Belief in the Last Day: It includes: (Belief in the punishment of the grave and its bliss, belief in Resurrection, belief in Gathering and Reckoning, belief in Paradise and Fire, and other matters of the Hereafter). 6) Belief in Destiny (Qadar), its good and its evil: It includes: (Belief that Allah Almighty knows everything generally and in detail, belief that Allah wrote that in the Preserved Tablet, that all beings only exist by the will of Allah Almighty, and belief that all beings are created by Allah Almighty). - Included in the study of Aqidah is the explanation of the doctrines of the sects that opposed the belief of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah in these six principles. Fruit of studying the science of Aqidah and its benefit: 1. Knowing the correct creed which is the root of religion, and the foundation of the call of the Messengers. A servant's faith is not complete nor accepted by Allah Almighty except with it. For this reason, Allah Almighty says: {And whoever denies the faith - his work has become worthless, and he, in the Hereafter, will be among the losers} [Al-Ma'idah: 5]. 2. Knowing that correct creed is a condition for the validity of deeds and their acceptance. 3. Knowing the greatest and most confirmed duties is the Tawhid (Monotheism) of Allah Almighty, and distancing from what contradicts it of associating partners with Allah (Shirk) and the like. 4. Correct creed is the reason for obtaining establishment on earth, and uniting the ranks of Muslims, and upon it their word unites. 5. Through it, security and stability, and happiness in this world and the Hereafter are achieved.
foot_note: None

text: 6. Knowing the doctrines of deviant sects and warning against them. 7. Immunity against deviant heretical sects. 8. Studying correct creed increases a person in fear of Allah, and distance from sins and mortal crimes. 9. Islamic civilization is only established on correct creed; because every structure, whether material or moral, must have an ideological foundation upon which it stands. Terminology in the Science of Aqidah: Religion (Din): It is the religion of Islam and the creed of Tawhid which is the religion of all Messengers from Adam and Noah to the Seal of Prophets, Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. Faith (Iman): Affirmation with the heart, speech with the tongue, and action with the limbs; it increases with obedience and decreases with disobedience. Islamic Aqidah: It is firm belief in Allah Almighty and what is due to Him of Tawhid and obedience, and in His angels, Books, Messengers, the Last Day, and Destiny, and all that is proven of matters of the Unseen, reports, and principles, whether scientific (theoretical) or practical. Tawhid: Singling out Allah Almighty with what is specific to Him of Lordship, Divinity, and Names and Attributes. Fundamentals of Religion (Usul al-Din): Are the foundations upon which the Islamic religion stands and is built, and are considered a root for it, which the predecessors of this nation agreed upon.
foot_note: None

text: Sunnah: Used by the Salaf for what opposes Bid'ah (Innovation). So whoever follows the Sunnah of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and the Sunnah of the Companions and Followers and those after them, and follows their methodology, is said to be: from Ahl al-Sunnah. And whoever leaves their methodology and follows the people of desires is said to be: from the innovators (Mubtadi'ah). Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, says: The term 'Sunnah' in the speech of the Salaf includes Sunnah in acts of worship and in beliefs, although many who wrote on Sunnah intended discussion of beliefs. Al-Fiqh Al-Akbar (The Greater Understanding): A name for Aqidah given to it by some. The first to use the term (Al-Fiqh Al-Akbar) was Imam Abu Hanifa Al-Nu'man bin Thabit. This naming does not mean neglecting other jurisprudence (issues of rulings and Halal and Haram), but rather means caring for Aqidah and starting by correcting it before performing actions, and knowing its detailed evidences. Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah: They are those who follow what the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his companions were upon. They were named Ahl al-Sunnah: because of their adherence to and following of the Sunnah of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. They were named Al-Jama'ah: because they are the ones who gathered on the truth and did not separate in religion, and gathered around the Imams of truth and did not rebel against them, and followed what the predecessors of the nation agreed upon. Ahl al-Hadith: They are those attributed to the Hadith of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, due to their following of it. They are everyone who made the speech of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, a source of reception from which they derive the beliefs of Islam, whether they are scholars of Hadith, Fiqh, Usul al-Fiqh, or otherwise.
foot_note: None

text: Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, says: We do not mean by Ahl al-Hadith those restricted to hearing it, writing it, or narrating it. Rather we mean by them: everyone who was most deserving of memorizing it, knowing it, and understanding it outwardly and inwardly, and following it inwardly and outwardly, as well as the people of the Quran (1). Al-Salaf (The Predecessors): They are the forefront of this nation from the Companions and Followers, and the Imams of guidance in the three favored centuries. It applies to everyone who followed them and walked on their path in all ages. Al-Khalaf (The Successors): They are those who came after the three favored centuries, from Muslim scholars and their common folk. Al-Bid'ah (Innovation): An invented way in religion that resembles the Sharia, by following which the intention is the same as what is intended by the Sharia way (2).
foot_note:
1. Majmu' Al-Fatawa (4/ 95). 
2. Defined as such by Al-Shatibi in his book Al-I'tisam (1/ 51).

text: Fourth: Fiqh (Jurisprudence): The science of Fiqh is one of the most majestic Sharia sciences, for by it a person knows the rulings of Obligatory (Wajib), Recommended (Mandub), Permissible (Mubah), Disliked (Makruh), and Forbidden (Haram). Thus, the Muslim builds his worship and dealing with people according to the commands of Allah Almighty, and the commands of His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him; thereby attaining success in both abodes. Ibn Nujaym said in Al-Ashbah wa Al-Naza'ir: For Fiqh is the most noble of sciences in value, the greatest in reward, the most complete in return, the most general in benefit, the highest in rank, and the most brilliant in virtue. It fills the eyes with light, the hearts with joy, the chests with relief, and provides matters with breadth and openness (1). Definition of Fiqh: Fiqh in language: is understanding. It is said: So-and-so 'faqiha' my saying, i.e., understood it. From it is the saying of Allah Almighty: {And there is not a thing except that it exalts [Allah] by His praise, but you do not understand [la tafqahuna] their [way of] exalting} [Al-Isra: 44], i.e., you do not understand it. And the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: Whomever Allah wills good for, He gives him understanding (yufaqqih-hu) in the religion (2). And Fiqh in terminology: is the knowledge of practical Sharia rulings [derived] from their detailed evidences. Divisions of Fiqh: Scholars divided Fiqh into two main sections:
foot_note:
1. Al-Ashbah wa Al-Naza'ir p. (13). 
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1/ 25) No. (71), and Muslim (2/ 719) No. (1037).

text: Section One: Fiqh of Worship (Ibadat): It includes the practical rulings for the actions of the accountable person related to organizing the human's relationship with his Lord, such as: Purification, Prayer, Zakat, Fasting, Hajj, Vows, and others. Section Two: Fiqh of Transactions (Mu'amalat): It includes the rulings that organize people's relationships with one another, whether they are individuals or groups. These rulings branch into the following: First: Civil Rulings: Intended to organize individuals' financial relationships and preserve rights. It relates to individuals' transactions and exchanges such as sale, lease, pledge, guarantee, partnership, debt, fulfillment of obligations, and otherwise. Second: Family Rulings: Which has been named recently as (Personal Status): Intended to organize the relationship of spouses and relatives with one another. It relates to the Fiqh of marriage, divorce, alimony, custody, inheritance, endowments (Waqf), and the like. Third: Financial and Criminal Rulings: Intended to preserve people's lives, wealth, honor, and rights. It includes Hudud (prescribed punishments) and crimes, and relates to crimes committed by the accountable person and the punishments deserved for them. Fourth: Judicial Rulings: Such as issues of pleading or civil procedures intended to organize procedures to establish justice among people. It relates to judiciary, lawsuits, methods of proof by testimony and oath, presumptions, and others. Fifth: Rulings of Sharia Policy: It includes three types:
foot_note: None

text: 1 - Constitutional Rulings: Intended to define the relationship of the ruler with the ruled, and establish what rights individuals and groups have, and what duties are upon them. It relates to the system of governance and its principles. 2 - International Rulings: Intended to define the type of relationship, cooperation, and mutual respect between states. It relates to organizing the relationship of the Islamic state with other states in peace and war, and the relationship of non-Muslim citizens in the state, including Jihad and treaties. 3 - Economic Rulings: Intended to organize financial relationships between the rich and poor, and between the state and individuals. It relates to individuals' financial rights and obligations in the financial system, and the state's financial rights and duties, and organizing treasury resources and expenditures. Fruit of studying the science of Fiqh and its benefits: 1 - Attaining the pleasure of Allah Almighty and His success, and obtaining the goodness in the Hadith: Whomever Allah wills good for, He gives him understanding in the religion (1). 2 - Organizing the life of individuals and groups: Knowing the jurisprudential rulings related to people's actions helps the Muslim adhere to those rulings, of Halal and Haram, and regulates the lives of individuals and groups with a rational Sharia methodology, far from being influenced by whims and desires.
foot_note: 1. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Sahih (1/ 25) No. (71), and Muslim in his Sahih (2/ 719) No. (1037).

text: 3 - Solving human problems: Studying jurisprudential rulings provides the Muslim with legal solutions to social and economic problems that societies suffer from, such as poverty, unemployment, and others. 4 - Addressing emerging issues: Islamic jurisprudence, with its inherent methods for deriving Sharia rulings, helps the student know the Sharia rulings for life issues that arise in society, such as the ruling on insurance, IVF, and others. 5 - Confirming the suitability of Islam for every time and place: Islamic jurisprudence, with its ability to address emerging issues, generates in the Muslim a complete conviction of Islam's suitability for application in every time and place, and its ability to accommodate the developments of the age and the data of science. Terminology of the Science of Fiqh: The Madhhab (School of Thought): It is: What an Imam among the Imams goes to in issues of Ijtihad based on rules and principles he sees. The Madhhab: Is the jurisprudential path followed by each Imam among the Imams of Ijtihad in deriving rulings, in terms of their reliance on texts or opinion. The Four Madhhabs: Known jurisprudential schools that spread in the second century and beyond. They are the school of Imam Abu Hanifa Al-Nu'man, the school of Imam Malik bin Anas, the school of Imam Al-Shafi'i, and the school of Imam Ahmad bin Hanbal.
foot_note: None

text: Following is a brief overview of each one of them: - Imam Abu Hanifa, he is: Al-Nu'man bin Thabit Al-Kufi Al-Taymi, the Jurist. Born in Kufa in the year (80 AH), his origin is from Persia. The Hanafi school is attributed to him, though correctly it is not his compilation. He died in Iraq in the year (150 AH). - Imam Malik, he is: Malik bin Anas bin Malik bin Abi Amir Al-Asbahi, Al-Himyari Al-Madani Abu Abdullah, the Imam of the Abode of Migration. Born in the Prophetic Medina in the year (93 AH). The Maliki school is attributed to him. Among his works: Al-Muwatta. He died in Medina in the year (179 AH). - Imam Al-Shafi'i, he is: Muhammad bin Idris bin Al-Abbas bin Uthman Al-Shafi'i Al-Muttalibi Al-Qurashi Abu Abdullah. Born in Gaza in the year (150 AH). The Shafi'i school is attributed to him. Among his works are (Al-Risalah), and (Kitab Al-Umm). He died in Egypt in the year (204 AH). - Imam Ahmad: Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hanbal Abu Abdullah Al-Shaybani Al-Wa'ili, the Muhaddith, Imam of Ahl al-Sunnah. The Hanbali school is attributed to him. Born in Baghdad in the year (164 AH). Among his works are (Al-Musnad), and (The Refutation of the Jahmiyyah and Heretics). He died in Egypt [Note: Error in source, he died in Baghdad] in the year (241 AH) [Note: Error in source text says 204]. Al-Zahiriyyah: A known jurisprudential school, named so due to taking the apparent meaning (Zahir) of texts and not considering causation and analogy. The founder of this school is Dawud bin Ali Al-Zahiri, and Ibn Hazm Al-Andalusi came after him and established foundations for this school and set its rules.
foot_note: None

text: Fard (Obligation): What the Sharia demanded to be done with a decisive demand, such that reward results from doing it, just as punishment results from leaving it. Fard 'Ayni (Individual Obligation): What is demanded to be done by every single individual among the accountable persons with a decisive demand. Fard Kifa'i (Communal Obligation): What is demanded to be done by the collective of accountable persons, not by every single one of them specifically. Meaning: If enough accountable persons perform it, the sin falls from the rest of the accountable persons, and if no one performs it, they all sin, and are disobedient to Allah, Lord of the Worlds. Rukn (Pillar): It is that without which a thing is not complete, and it is part of it and included in its reality. Mandub (Recommended): What the Sharia demanded with a non-decisive demand, i.e., reward results from doing it, and no punishment results from leaving it. Mubah (Permissible): That whose doing and leaving are equal; because the Lawgiver did not command us to leave it, nor did He command us to do it; rather He gave us the freedom of leaving and doing and made them equal in degree. Therefore, neither reward nor punishment results from doing the Mubah or leaving it. Haram (Forbidden): What the Sharia demanded us to leave with a decisive leaving, such that reward results from leaving it in compliance with Allah's command, and punishment results from doing it. Makruh (Disliked): What the Lawgiver demanded to be left with a non-decisive demand, such that if we leave it in compliance with Allah Almighty's command we are rewarded for it, and if we do it we are not punished. Ada' (Performance): Doing the act of worship in the time limited for it by the Sharia. Qada' (Making Up): Doing the act of worship that became obligatory outside the time defined for it by the Sharia. I'adah (Repetition): Doing the act of worship in its time a second time for increased virtue.
foot_note: None

text: Fifth: Principles of Jurisprudence (Usul al-Fiqh): The science of Usul al-Fiqh: is among the most majestic sciences in value and greatest in importance, as it is the science considered by scholars as a basis for establishing proofs, refining issues, and deriving Sharia rulings. Its status in Sharia sciences is great as understanding rulings and knowing their causes relates to it. Definition of Usul al-Fiqh: Usul: Plural of Asl (Root/Origin). Asl in language: What something else is built upon. Usul al-Fiqh technically: Is the science that investigates general jurisprudential evidences, how to benefit from them, and the condition of the beneficiary. Divisions of Usul al-Fiqh: The topics of Usul al-Fiqh are divided into four main sections: 1. Explanation of Rulings: Such as prohibition, dislike, obligation, recommendation, permissibility, condition, impediment, and cause. And validity and invalidity, etc. 2. Study of Evidences: Such as the Book, the Sunnah, Consensus (Ijma'), Analogy (Qiyas), Juristic Preference (Istihsan), Presumption of Continuity (Istishab), Statement of a Companion, Blocking the Means (Sadd al-Dhara'i), and Public Interest (Maslahah Mursalah). 3. Modes of Indication of Evidences: Specific and General, Ambiguous and Clarified, Absolute and Restricted, Command and Prohibition, Abrogating and Abrogated, and the like. 4. Condition of the Deductor and the One Deducted For: These are the conditions of the Mujtahid and conditions of Ijtihad, rulings of following and followers, and rulings of imitation (Taqlid) and imitators.
foot_note: None

text: Fruit of studying the science of Usul al-Fiqh and its benefits: 1) It gives the learner strength in deriving Sharia rulings from subsidiary evidences. 2) Facilitating the process of Ijtihad and giving new occurrences their appropriate rulings. 3) Knowing the controls of Fatwa, and the conditions and etiquette of the Mufti. 4) Protecting Islamic jurisprudence from openness resulting from establishing new sources of legislation, and from rigidity resulting from the claim of closing the door of Ijtihad. 5) Controlling the rules of dialogue and debate, by referring to authentic considered evidences. 6) Recognizing the tolerance and ease of Islamic Sharia, and viewing the beauties of this religion. 7) Clarifying methods of reconciling evidences that seemingly contradict, and refuting the doubts of detractors regarding that. 8) Preserving Islamic Sharia, because the science of Usul al-Fiqh safeguards the evidences of legislation so people do not transgress them, just as it preserves for rulings their arguments and documents, and clarifies the original and subsidiary sources of legislation so that the Sharia retains its rules. 9) Preventing the interpretation of texts of the Book and Sunnah according to opinion or desire. The science of Usul al-Fiqh controls the interpretation of texts, and governs it with comprehensive universal controls and rules agreed upon that refute every transgressor.
foot_note: None

text: 10) In it is salvation and protection from division and difference, which arises from incorrect understanding of the Quran and Sunnah. Through it, the school of Hadith and Athar and the school of Ahl al-Ra'y (People of Opinion) were united. 11) Acquiring the jurisprudential faculty (Malakah) that enables the student of knowledge or jurist to understand correctly, fully and comprehensively perceive jurisprudential rulings, view methods of deduction and Ijtihad to benefit from them, and use analogy based on them if needed. 12) Removing sectarian fanaticism among jurists, where the student of knowledge can, through studying Usul al-Fiqh, balance between schools and jurisprudential opinions, and know the most likely, correct, and most worthy of acceptance, based on evidence and fundamental rules. Terminology of the Science of Usul al-Fiqh: Ijtihad: Is expending effort in extracting rulings from their evidences indicating them by looking into that which leads to them. Ijma' (Consensus): Is the agreement of the Mujtahids of the Ummah after the death of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, in any era, on a Sharia ruling. Qiyas (Analogy): Referring a branch to an origin in a specific ruling, due to a common cause between them. Shar' man qablana (Laws of those before us): Are the rulings transmitted to us in the Quran or established Sunnah that were laws for previous nations, like the People of the Book and others.
foot_note: None

text: Urf (Custom): Is what most people are familiar with, and agree upon in actions, and there is no Sharia evidence negating or affirming it. Sadd al-Dhara'i (Blocking the Means): Cutting off the substance of means to corruption by preventing these means and repelling them. Example: Forbidding Muslims from insulting the gods of polytheists for fear that the polytheists would respond by insulting Allah Almighty. This prohibition came in His saying: {And do not insult those they invoke other than Allah, lest they insult Allah in enmity without knowledge} [Al-An'am: 108]. Al-Maslahah Al-Mursalah (Public Interest): Is every interest for which no specific evidence has come from the Lawgiver indicating its consideration or cancellation, and was consistent with the objectives of the Lawgiver. Example: Compiling the Quran in one Mushaf. The Companions agreed on it and there was no text for it, but the interest of preserving the religion required it. Sabab (Cause): What necessitates existence from its existence, and non-existence from its non-existence essentially. It is what something else is linked to in existence and non-existence; so existence of the effect follows from existence of the cause, and non-existence of the effect follows from non-existence of the cause, due to the cause itself. Example: Marriage is a cause for inheritance. Existence of inheritance between spouses follows from existence of marriage, and non-existence of inheritance follows from non-existence of marriage, due to the cause itself; because marriage might exist but the effect (inheritance) fails due to the presence of an impediment, like difference of religion. Shart (Condition): What necessitates non-existence from its non-existence, but existence nor non-existence does not necessitate from its existence essentially. It is what something else is linked to in non-existence not existence. If the condition is absent the ruling is absent, but if the condition is present the ruling might exist or might not.
foot_note: None

text: Example: Purification is a condition; invalidity of prayer follows from its absence, but validity of prayer does not necessarily follow from its presence; because purity might exist (ritual impurity lifted) but another condition fails, preventing the validity of prayer. Mani' (Impediment): What necessitates non-existence from its existence, and neither existence nor non-existence necessitates from its non-existence essentially. It is what something else is linked to in existence not non-existence. If the impediment is found, the ruling is absent, and neither existence nor non-existence of the ruling necessitates from its absence essentially. Example: If menstruation is found, the validity of prayer is non-existent, but the validity of prayer does not necessarily follow from the absence of menstruation; because another impediment might exist. Amr (Command): Is requesting an action by speech from a position of superiority. Our saying: (from a position of superiority) means: that the command came from the higher to the lower. Example: His saying Almighty: {And establish prayer and give zakah and bow with those who bow} ... [Al-Baqarah: 43]. In the verse, Allah commanded His servants to pray and give Zakat. The direction of superiority here: The Highest is Allah Almighty, and the lowest are the servants. Nahy (Prohibition): Is the speech requesting abstention from a position of superiority. Example: His saying Almighty: {O you who have believed, do not approach prayer while you are intoxicated} [An-Nisa: 43]. Aam (General): Is the term encompassing all its individuals without restriction. Khas (Specific): Is the term indicating a restricted number. Example of General and Specific: {And [due] to Allah from the people is a pilgrimage to the House - for whoever is able to find thereto a way} [Al Imran: 97]. His saying: {And [due] to Allah from the people is a pilgrimage to the House} is general including all people,
foot_note: None

text: and His saying: {for whoever is able to find thereto a way} specified this generality with a description, which is the description of ability. Mutlaq (Absolute/Unrestricted): Is the term indicating the reality/essence without restriction. Example: His saying Almighty regarding expiation for Zihar: {And those who pronounce thihar from their wives and then [wish to] go back on what they said - then [there must be] the freeing of a slave before they touch one another} [Al-Mujadila: 3]. Here, freeing any slave was mentioned in the expiation, whether believing or disbelieving. Muqayyad (Restricted): Is the term indicating the reality/essence with a restriction; such as unity, description, condition, time, place, or others. Example: His saying Almighty regarding expiation for accidental killing: {And whoever kills a believer by mistake - then the freeing of a believing slave} [An-Nisa: 92]. Here, a restriction was mentioned for the slave in the expiation, which is that he must be a believer, not just any slave. Mantuq (Explicit/Spoken Meaning): Is what the wording indicates in the place of utterance. It is the meaning derived from the wording in terms of it being spoken. Mafhum (Implied/Understood Meaning): Is what the wording indicates in other than the place of utterance. It is a meaning understood and derived from the wording. Example of Explicit and Implied: {So do not say to them [parents] "uff"} [Al-Isra: 23]. The explicit meaning of the verse is the prohibition of saying "uff" to parents, which is uttering "uff". The implied meaning of the verse is the prohibition of hitting and cursing. These are the most prominent terms related to the science of Usul al-Fiqh.
